scenepersonae.scenepersona: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster
Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

stagedir.dir: Enter hastily at several doors the Dukes of Lancaster and York, the Earls of Arundel and Surrey, with napkins on their arms and knives in their hands, and Sir Thomas Cheney with others bearing torches and some with cloaks and rapiers.

speech.speaker: ALL LORDS.
speech.line: Lights, lights! Bring torches, knaves!

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Shut to the gates!
Let no man out until the house be search’d!

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Call for our coaches, let’s away, good brother!
Now by th’ bless’d saints, I fear we are poison’d all!

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Poison’d, my lord?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, ay, good Arundel, ’tis high time begone.
May heaven be bless’d for this prevention.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: God, for thy mercy! Would our cousin king
So cozen us, to poison us in our meat?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Has no man here some helping antidote
For fear already we have ta’en some dram?
What thinkest thou, Cheney?
Thou first brought’st the tidings.
Are we not poison’d, thinkest thou?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Fear not, my lords,
That mischievous potion was as yet unserv’d.
It was a liquid bane dissolv’d in wine
Which after supper should have been carous’d
To young King Richard’s health.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Good i’ faith! Are his uncles’ deaths become
Health to King Richard? How came it out?
Sir Thomas Cheney, pray resolve this doubt.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: A Carmelite friar, my lord, reveal’d the plot
And should have acted it, but touch’d in conscience
He came to your good brother, the Lord Protector,
And so disclos’d it; who straight sent me to you.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: The Lord protect him for it, ay, and our cousin King.
High heaven be judge, we wish all good to him.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: A heavy charge, good Woodstock, hast thou had,
To be Protector to so wild a prince
So far degenerate from his noble father,
Whom the trembling French the Black Prince call’d,
Not of a swart and melancholy brow
(For sweet and lovely was his countenance)
But that he made so many funeral days
In mournful France: the warlike battles won
At Crécy Field, Poitiers, Artoise and Maine
Made all France groan under his conquering arm.
But heaven forestall’d his diadem on earth
To place him with a royal crown in heaven.
Rise may his dust to glory! Ere he’d ’a done
A deed so base unto his enemy,
Much less unto the brothers of his father,
He’d first have lost his royal blood in drops,
Dissolv’d the strings of his humanity
And lost that livelihood that was preserv’d
To make his (unlike) son a wanton king.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Forbear, good John of Gaunt! Believe me, brother,
We may do wrong unto our cousin King:
I fear his flattering minions more than him.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: By the bless’d Virgin, noble Edmund York,
I’m past all patience. Poison his subjects,
His royal uncles! Why, the proud Castilian,
Where John of Gaunt writes King and Sovereign,
Would not throw off their vile and servile yoke
By treachery so base. Patience, gracious Heaven!

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: A good invoke, right princely Lancaster,
Calm thy high spleen. Sir Thomas Cheney here
Can tell the circumstance; pray give him leave.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Well, let him speak.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: ’Tis certainly made known, my reverend lords,
To your lov’d brother and the good Protector,
That not King Richard but his flatterers
Sir Henry Green, join’d with Sir Edward Bagot,
And that sly machiavel, Tresilian,
Whom now the King elects for Lord Chief Justice
Had all great hands in this conspiracy.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: By blessed Mary, I’ll confound them all!

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Your spleen confounds yourself.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: By kingly Edward’s soul, my royal father,
I’ll be reveng’d at full on all their lives.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Nay, if your rage break to such high extremes
You will prevent yourself, and lose revenge.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Why, Edmund, can’st thou give a reason yet
Though we, so near in blood, his hapless uncles,
(His grandsire Edward’s sons, his father’s brothers!)
Should thus be made away? Why might it be
That Arundel and Surrey here should die?

speech.speaker: SUR.
speech.line: Some friend of theirs wanted my earldom sore.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Perhaps my office of the Admiralty
If a better and more fortunate hand could govern it
I would ’twere none of mine
Yet thus much can I say, and make my praise
No more than merit: a wealthier prize
Did never yet take harbor in our roads
Than I to England brought. You all can tell,
Full three-score sail of tall and lusty ships
And six great carracks fraught with oil and wines
I brought King Richard in abundance home,
So much, that plenty hath so stal’d our palates
As that a tun of high-pric’d wines of France
Is hardly worth a mark of English money.
If service such as this done to my country
Merit my heart to bleed, let it bleed freely.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: We’ll bleed together, warlike Arundel.
Cousin of Surrey, princely Edmund York,
Let’s think on some revenge. If we must die,
Ten thousand souls shall keep us company.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Patience, good Lancaster. Tell me, kind Cheney,
How does thy master, our good brother Woodstock,
Plain Thomas? For by th’ rood, so all men call him,
For his plain dealing and his simple clothing.
Let others jet in silk and gold, says he,
A coat of English frieze best pleaseth me.
How thinks his unsophisticated plainness
Of these bitter compounds? Fears he no drug
Put in his broth? Shall his healths be secure?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Faith, my lord, his mind suits with his habit:
Homely and plain, both free from pride and envy,
And therein will admit distrust to none.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Duke of Gloucester, Thomas of Woodstock, in frieze, the Mace carried before him, the Lord Mayor of London, and Sir Pierce of Exton, and others with lights before them.

speech.line: And see, his Grace himself is come to greet you.
By your leave there, room for my Lord Protector’s Grace!

speech.speaker: YORK. AND LAN.
speech.line: Health to your Grace.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: I salute your healths, good brothers; pray pardon me,
I’ll speak with you anon. Hie thee, good Exton.
Good Lord Mayor, I do beseech ye prosecute
With your best care a means for all our safeties.
Mischief hath often double practices;
Treachery wants not his second stratagem.
Who knows but steel may hit, though poison fail?
Alack the day, the night is made a veil
To shadow mischief. Set, I beseech,
Strong guard and careful to attend the city.
Our Lady help, we know not who are friends,
Our foes are grown so mighty. Pray be careful.

speech.speaker: LORD MAY.
speech.line: Your friends are great in London, good my lord.
I’ll front all dangers, trust it on my word.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Thanks from my heart.
I swear afore my God,
I know not which way to bestow myself,
The time’s so busy and so dangerous too.
Why, how now, brothers? How fares good John o’ Gaunt?
Thou’rt vex’d, I know. Thou griev’st, kind Edmund York.
Arundel and Surrey, noble kinsmen,
I know ye all are discontented much,
But be not so. Afore my God, I swear
King Richard loves you all; and credit me,
The princely gentleman is innocent
Of this black deed and base conspiracy.
Speak, speak, how is’t with princely Lancaster?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Sick, Gloucester, sick. We all are weary
And fain we would lie down to rest ourselves,
But that so many serpents lurk i’ the grass
We dare not sleep.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Enough, enough,
Good brother, I have found out the disease:
When the head aches, the body is not healthful.
King Richard’s wounded with a wanton humor,
Lull’d and secur’d by flattering sycophants;
But ’tis not deadly yet, it may be cur’d.
Some vein let blood where the corruption lies
And all shall heal again.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Then lose no time, lest it grow ulcerous.
The false Tresilian, Green and Bagot
Run naught but poison, brother, spill them all.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: They guide the nonage King; ’tis they protect him.
Ye wear the title of Protectorship
But like an under-officer, as though
Yours were deriv’d from theirs. Faith, you’re too plain!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: In my apparel, you’ll say.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Good faith, in all.
The commons murmur ’gainst the dissolute king,
Treason is whisper’d at each common table
As customary as their thanks to heaven.
Men need not gaze up to the sky to see
Whether the sun shine clear or no, ’tis found
By the small light should beautify the ground.
Conceit you me, a blind man thus much sees:
He wants his eyes to whom we bend our knees.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: You all are princes of the royal blood
Yet like great oaks ye let the ivy grow
To eat your hearts out with his false embraces.
Ye understand, my lord?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ay, ay, good coz, as if ye plainly said
Destroy those flatterers and tell King Richard
He does abase himself to countenance them.
Soft, soft!
Fruit that grows high is not securely pluck’d,
We must use ladders and by steps ascend
Till by degrees we reach the altitude.
You conceit me too? Pray be smooth awhile.
Tomorrow is the solemn nuptial day
Betwixt the King and virtuous Anne a’ Beame,
The Emperor’s daughter, a right gracious lady
That’s come to England for King Richard’s love.
Then, as you love his Grace, and hate his flatterers,
Discountenance not the day with the least frown,
Be ignorant of what ye know. Afore my God,
I have good hope this happy marriage, brothers,
Of this so noble and religious princess,
Will mildly calm his headstrong youth, to see
And shun those stains that blurs his majesty.
If not, by good King Edward’s bones, our royal father,
I will remove those hinderers of his health,
Though’t cost my head.

speech.speaker: YORK. AND LAN.
speech.line: On these conditions, brother, we agree.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: And I.

speech.speaker: SUR.
speech.line: And I.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: To hide our hate is soundest policy.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: And, brother Gloucester, since it is your pleasure
To have us smooth our sullen brows with smiles,
We’d have you suit your outside to your heart,
And like a courtier cast this country habit
For which the coarse and vulgar call your Grace
By the title of Plain Thomas: yet we doubt not
Tomorrow we shall have good hope to see
Your High Protectorship in bravery.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: No, no, good York, this is as fair a sight,
My heart in this plain frieze sits true and right.
In this I’ll serve my King as true and bold
As if my outside were all trapp’d in gold.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: By Mary, but you shall not, brother Woodstock!
What, the marriage-day to Richard and his Queen,
And will ye so disgrace the state and realm?
We’ll have you brave, i’faith!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Well, well,
For your sakes, brothers, and this solemn day,
For once I’ll sumpter a gaudy wardrobe, but ’tis more
Than I have done, I vow, these twenty years.
Afore my God, the King could not have entreated me
To leave this habit, but your wills be done.
Let’s hie to court, you all your wishes have;
One weary day, Plain Thomas will be brave.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Henry Green, Sir Edward Bagot, and Sir Robert Tresilian, in a rage.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Nay, good Sir Henry, King Richard calls for you.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Prithee, sweet Green,
Visit his Highness and forsake these passions.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: ’Sblood, I am vex’d, Tresilian, mad me not!
Thyself and I and all are now undone.
The lords at London are secur’d from harm,
The plot’s reveal’d. Black curses seize the traitor!

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Eternal torments whip that Carmelite!

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: A deeper hell than Limbo Patrum hold him,
A fainting villain, confusion crush his soul!

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Could the false slave recoil, and swore their deaths!

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Mischief devour him! Had it but ta’en effect
On Lancaster and Edmund, Duke of York,
Those headstrong uncles to the gentle King,
The third brother, plain Thomas, the Protector,
Had quickly been remov’d; but since ’tis thus,
Our safeties must be car’d for, and ’tis best
To keep us near the person of the King.
Had they been dead, we had rul’d the realm and him.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: So shall we still, so long as Richard lives.
I know he cannot brook his stubborn uncles.
Come, think not on’t: cheer thee, Tresilian,
Here’s better news for thee: we have so wrought
With kingly Richard, that by his consent
You are already mounted on your footcloth
(Your scarlet or your purple, which ye please)
And shortly are to underprop the name
Mark me, Tresilianof Lord Chief Justice of England!

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Hum, hum, hum, legit or non legit ? Methinks already I sit upon the bench with dreadful frowns frighting the lousy rascals; and when the jury once cries ‘Guilty’ could pronounce ‘Lord have mercy on thee,’ with a brow as rough and stern as surly Rhadamanth; or, when a fellow talks, cry: ‘Take him, jailor, clap bolts of iron on his heels and hands!’
Chief Justice, my lords! Hum, hum, hum, I will wear the office in his true ornament.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: But good your Honor, as ’twill shortly be,
You must observe and fashion to the time
The habit of your laws. The King is young,
Ay, and a little wanton. So perhaps are we:
Your laws must not be beadles then, Tresilian,
To punish your benefactors; look to that.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: How, sir, to punish you, the minions to the King,
The jewels of his heart, his dearest loves?
’Zounds, I will screw and wind the stubborn law
To any fashion that shall like you best.
It shall be law, what I shall say is law,
And what’s most suitable to all your pleasures.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Thanks to your Lordship, which is yet to come!

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Farewell, Tresilian, still be near the court,
Anon King Richard shall confirm thy state.
We must attend his Grace to Westminster
To the high nuptials of fair Anne a’ Beame,
That must be now his wife and England’s queen.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: So, let them pass. Tresilian, now bethink thee.
Hum, Lord Chief Justice!Methinks already
I am swell’d more plump than erst I was.
Authority’s a dish that feeds men fat,
An excellent delicate. Yet best be wise,
No state’s secure without some enemies!
The dukes will frown; why, I can look as grim
As John of Gaunt, and all that frown with him.
But yet until mine office be put on
By kingly Richard, I’ll conceal myself,
Framing such subtle laws that Janus-like
May with a double face salute them both.
I’ll search my brain and turn the leaves of law:
Wit makes us great, greatness keeps fools in awe.
My man there, ho! Where’s Nimble?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: As nimble as an eel, sir. Did ye call, sir?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Sir! Look out some better phrase, salute again.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I know no other, sir, unless you’ll be Frenchified and let me lay the Monsieur to your charge, or Sweet Signior.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Neither, ’tis higher yet, Nimble, thou buckram scribe. Think once again.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Neither Sir, nor Monsieur, nor Signior! What should I call him? Trow, he’s monstrously translated suddenly! At first, when we were schoolfellows, then I call’d him Sirrah, but since he became my master I par’d away the Ah and serv’d him with the Sir. What title he has got now, I know not, but I’ll try further.
Has your Worship any employment for me?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Thou gross uncaput, no, thou speakest not yet.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: My mouth was open, I’m sure!If your Honor would please to hear me

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Ha, Honor, say’st thou? Ay, now thou hittest it, Nimble.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I knew I should wind about ye till I had your Honor.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Nimble, bend thy knee,
The Lord Chief Justice of England speaks to thee!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: The Lord be prais’d! We shall have a flourishing commonwealth, sir.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Peace, let me speak to thee.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Yes, anything, so your Honor pray not for me, I care not; for now you’re Lord Chief Justice, if ever ye cry ‘Lord have mercy’ upon me, I shall hang for’t, sure!

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: No, those fearful words shall not be pronounc’d ’gainst thee, Nimble.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Thank ye, my lord. Nay, and you’ll stand between me and the gallows, I’ll be an arrant thief, sure. If I cannot pick up my crumbs by the law quickly, I’ll cast away my buckram bags and be a highway lawyer now, certainly.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Can’st thou remember, Nimble, how by degrees I rose, since first thou knew’st me? I was first a schoolboy

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Ay, saving your Honor’s speech, your worshipful tail was whipp’d for stealing my dinner out of my satchel. You were ever so crafty in your childhood that I knew your Worship would prove a good lawyer!

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Interrupt me not. Those days thou knew’st, I say,
From whence I did become a plodding clerk,
From which I bounc’d, as thou dost now, in buckram
To be a pleading lawyer, and there I stay’d
Till by the King I was Chief Justice made.
Nimble, I read this discipline to thee
To stir thy mind up still to industry.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Thank your good lordship.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Go to thy mistress, Lady you now must call her.
Bid her remove her household up to London.
Tell her our fortunes, and with how much peril
We have attain’d this place of eminence.
Go and remove her.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: With a Habeas Corpus or Surssararis, I assure ye. And so I leave your lordship, always hoping of your wonted favor, that when I have pass’d the London Bridge of Affliction I may arrive with you at the Westminster Hall of Promotion, and then I care not.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Thou shalt. Thou hast an executing look,
And I will put the ax into thy hand.
I rule the law, thou by the law shalt stand.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I thank your lordship, and a fig for the rope, then!

scenepersonae.scenepersona: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster
Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

stagedir.dir: Sound a sennet. Enter in great state King Richard and Queen Anne, crowned; Lancaster, York, Arundel and Surrey, Green, Bagot; and Woodstock, very brave; the Duchess of Gloucester and the Duchess of Ireland.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Bagot and Green, next to the fair Queen Anne
Take your high places by King Richard’s side,
And give fair welcome to our queen and bride.
Uncles of Woodstock, York, and Lancaster,
Make full our wishes, and salute our queen;
Give all your welcomes to fair Anne a’ Beame.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I hope, sweet prince, her Grace mistakes us not
To make our hearts the worser part of us;
Our tongues have, in our English eloquence,
Harsh though it is, pronounc’d her welcomes many
By oaths and loyal protestations
To which we add a thousand infinites;
But in a word, fair queen, forever welcome!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Let me prevent the rest, for mercy’s sake!
If all their welcomes be as long as thine
This health will not go round this week, by th’ Mass!
Sweet queen and cousin now I’ll call you so
In plain and honest phrase, welcome to England!
Think they speak all in me, and you have seen
All England cry with joy, ‘God bless the Queen!’
And so, afore my God, I know they wish it.
Only, I fear my duty not misconstred
Nay, nay, King Richard, ’fore God I’ll speak the truth!
Sweet Queen, you’ve found a young and wanton choice,
A wild-head, yet a kingly gentleman,
A youth unsettled, yet he’s princely bred,
Descended from the royal’st bloods in Europe,
The kingly stock of England and of France.
Yet he’s a harebrain, a very wag, i’faith.
But you must bear, madam: ’las, he’s but a blossom;
But his maturity, I hope you’ll find,
True English-bred, a king loving and kind.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I thank ye for your double praise, good uncle.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ay, ay, good coz, I’m Plain Thomas; by th’ rood
I’ll speak the truth.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: My sovereign lord, and you true English peers,
Your all-accomplish’d honors have so tied
My senses by a magical restraint
In the sweet spells of these your fair demeanors,
That I am bound and charm’d from what I was.
My native country I no more remember
But as a tale told in my infancy,
The greatest part forgot; and that which is,
Appears to England’s fair Elysium
Like brambles to the cedars, coarse to fine,
Or like the wild grape to the fruitful vine.
And, having left the earth where I was bred,
And English made, let me be Englished.
They best shall please me shall me English call.
My heart, great King, to you; my love to all!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Gramercy, Nan, thou highly honor’st me.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: And bless’d is England in this sweet accord.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Afore my God, sweet Queen, our English ladies,
And all the women that this isle contains,
Shall sing in praise of this your memory
And keep records of virtuous Anne a’ Beame,
Whose discipline hath taught them womanhood.
What erst seemed well by custom, now looks rude.
Our women, till your coming, fairest cousin,
Did use like men to straddle when they ride,
But you have taught them now to sit aside.
Yet (by your leave) young practice often reels;
I have seen some of your scholars kick up both their heels!

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: What have you seen, my lord?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Nay, nay, nothing, wife.
I see little without spectacles, thou know’st.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Trust him not, aunt, for now he’s grown so brave
He will be courting, ay, and kissing too.
Nay, uncle, now I’ll do as much for you,
And lay your faults all open to the world!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ay, ay, do, do.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I’m glad you’re grown so careless: now, by my crown,
I swear, good uncles York and Lancaster,
When you this morning came to visit me
I did not know him in this strange attire.
How comes this golden metamorphosis
From homespun huswifery? Speak, good uncle!
I never saw you hatch’d and gilded thus.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: I am no Stoic, my dear sovereign cousin,
To make my plainness seem canonical,
But to allow myself such ornaments
As might be fitting for your nuptial day
And coronation of your virtuous queen;
But were the eye of day once clos’d again,
Upon this back they never more should come.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: You have much grac’d the day. But, noble uncle,
I did observe what I have wonder’d at:
As we today rode on to Westminster,
Methought your horse, that ’s wont to tread the ground
And pace as if he kick’d it scornfully,
Mount and curvet like strong Bucephalus,
Today he trod as slow and melancholy
As if his legs had fail’d to bear his load.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: And can ye blame the beast? Afore my God,
He was not wont to bear such loads. Indeed,
A hundred oaks upon these shoulders hang
To make me brave upon your wedding-day.
And more than that, to make my horse more tire,
Ten acres of good land are stitch’d up here.
You know, good coz, this was not wont to be.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: In your t’other hose, uncle?

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: No, nor his frieze coat, neither!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ay, ay, mock on. My t’other hose, say ye?
There’s honest plain dealing in my t’other hose.
Should this fashion last I must raise new rents,
Undo my poor tenants, turn away my servants,
And guard myself with lace; nay, sell more land
And lordships too, by th’ rood. Hear me, King Richard:
If thus I jet in pride, I still shall lose,
But I’ll build castles in my t’other hose.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: The King but jests, my lord, and you grow angry.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: T’other hose! Did some here wear that fashion
They would not tax and pill the commons so!

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, he forewarn’d us, and will break out himself.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: No matter, we’ll back him, though it grows to blows.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Scoff ye my plainness? I’ll talk no riddles,
Plain Thomas will speak plainly: there’s Bagot there,
And Green—

speech.speaker: GREEN. AND BAG.
speech.line: And what of them, my lord?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Upstarts, come down, you have no places there!
Here’s better men to grace King Richard’s chair,
If’t please’d him grace them so.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Uncle, forbear.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: These cuts the columns that should prop thy house.
They tax the poor, and I am scandal’d for it
That, by my fault, those late oppressions rise
To set the commons in a mutiny
That London even itself was sack’d by them!
And who did all these rank commotions point at?
Even at these two, Bagot, here, and Green,
With false Tresilian, whom your Grace, we hear,
Hath made Chief Justice. Well, well, be it so,
Mischief on mischief sure will shortly flow.
Pardon my speech, my lord since now we’re all so brave
To grace Queen Anne, this day we’ll spend in sport;
But in my t’other hose, I’ll tickle them for’t.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Come, come, ye dote, my lord.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Dote, sir? Know ye to whom ye speak?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: No more, good uncles; come, sweet Green, ha’ done.
I’ll wring them all for this, by England’s crown!
Why is our Lord Protector so outrageous?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Because thy subjects have such outrage shown them
By these, thy flatterers. Let the sun dry up
What th’ unwholesome fog hath chok’d the ground with.
Here’s Arundel, thy ocean’s Admiral,
Hath brought thee home a rich and wealthy prize,
Ta’en three-score sail of ships and six great carracks,
All richly laden; let those goods be sold
To satisfy those borrowed sums of coin
Their pride hath forced from the needy commons:
To salve which inconvenience I beseech your Grace
You would vouchsafe to let me have the sale
And distribution of those goods.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Our word, good uncle, is already pass’d,
Which cannot with our honor be recall’d:
Those wealthy prizes already are bestow’d
On these our friends.

speech.speaker: ALL LORDS.
speech.line: On them, my lord?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Yes. Who storms at it?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Shall cankers eat the fruit
That planting and good husbandry hath nourish’d?

speech.speaker: GREEN. AND BAG.
speech.line: Cankers?

speaker.long: Duke of York and Earl of Arundel

speech.speaker: YORK. AND ARUN.
speech.line: Ay, cankers! Caterpillars!

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Worse than consuming fires
That eats up all their furies falls upon.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Once more, be still!
Who is’t that dares encounter with our will?
We did bestow them. Hear me, kind uncles:
We shall ere long be past protectorship.
Then will we rule ourself, and even till then
We let ye know those gifts are given to them.
We did it, Woodstock.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ye have done ill, then.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ha, dare ye say so?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Dare I? Afore my God, I’ll speak, King Richard,
Were I assur’d this day my head should off.
I tell ye, sir, my allegiance stands excus’d
In justice of the cause. Ye have done ill,
The sun of mercy never shine on me
But I speak truth. When warlike Arundel,
Beset at sea, fought for those wealthy prizes,
He did with fame advance the English cross,
Still crying, ‘Courage, in King Richard’s name!’
For thee he won them, and do thou enjoy them,
He’ll fetch more honors home. But had he known
That kites should have enjoy’d the eagle’s prize
The fraught had swum unto thine enemies.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: So, sir. We’ll soothe your vexed spleen, good uncle,
And mend what is amiss. To those slight gifts,
Not worth acceptance, thus much more we add:
Young Henry Green shall be Lord Chancellor,
Bagot, Lord Keeper of our Privy Seal,
Tresilian, learned in our kingdom’s laws,
Shall be Chief Justice. By them and their directions
King Richard will uphold his government.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Change no more words, my lord, ye do deject
Your kingly majesty to speak to such
Whose homespun judgments, like their frosty beards,
Would blast the blooming hopes of all your kingdom.
Were I as you, my lord

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Oh, gentle Green, throw no more fuel on,
But rather seek to mitigate this heat.
Be patient, kingly Richard, quench this ire.
Would I had tears of force to stint this fire!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Beshrew the churls that makes my queen so sad,
But by my grandsire Edward’s kingly bones,
My princely father’s tomb, King Richard swears
We’ll make them weep these wrongs in bloody tears!
Come, fair Queen Anne a’ Beame. Bagot and Green,
Keep by King Richard’s side;
but as for you,
We’ll shortly make your stiff obedience bow.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Remember this, my lords:
We keep the Seal. Our strength you all shall know.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: And we are Chancellor. We love you well, think so.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: God for His mercy! Shall we brook these braves,
Disgrac’d and threaten’d thus by fawning knaves?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Shall we, that were great Edward’s princely sons,
Be thus outbrav’d by flattering sycophants?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Afore my God and holy saints, I swear,
But that my tongue hath liberty to show
The inly passions boiling in my breast,
I think my overburden’d heart would break!
What then may we conjecture? What’s the cause
Of this remiss and inconsiderate dealing
Urg’d by the King and his confederates,
But hate to virtue, and a mind corrupt
With all preposterous rude misgovernment?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: These prizes ta’en by warlike Arundel
Before his face are given those flatterers!

speech.speaker: SUR.
speech.line: It is his custom to be prodigal
To any but to those do best deserve.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Because he knew you would bestow them well,
He gave it such as for their private gain
Neglect both honor and their country’s good.
Wind horns within

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: How now, what noise is this?

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Some posts, it seems, pray heaven the news be good.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Amen, I pray for England’s happiness.
Speak, speak, what tidings, Cheney?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Of war, my lord, and civil dissension.
The men of Kent and Essex do rebel.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: I thought no less and always fear’d as much.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: The shrieves in post have sent unto your Grace
That order may be ta’en to stay the commons
For fear rebellion rise in open arms.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Now, headstrong Richard, shalt thou reap the fruit
Thy lewd, licentious willfulness hath sown.
I know not which way to bestow myself!

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: There is no standing on delay, my lords,
These hot eruptions must have some redress,
Or else in time they’ll grow incurable.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: The commons, they rebel; and the King, all careless,
Heaps wrong on wrong, to stir more mutiny.
Afore my God, I know not what to do!

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Take open arms. Join with the vexed commons,
And hale his minions from his wanton side.
Their heads cut off, the people’s satisfied.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Not so, not so! Alack the day, good brother,
We may not so affright the tender prince.
We’ll bear us nobly, for the kingdom’s safety
And the King’s honor. Therefore, list to me.
You, brother Gaunt and noble Arundel,
Shall undertake by threats or fair entreaty
To pacify the murmuring commons’ rage;
And whiles you there employ your service hours,
We presently will call a parliament
And have their deeds examin’d thoroughly;
Where, if by fair means we can win no favor,
Nor make King Richard leave their companies,
We’ll thus resolve for our dear country’s good
To right her wrongs, or for it spend our bloods.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: About it, then: we for the Commons, you for the Court.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ay, ay, good Lancaster, I pray be careful.
Come, brother York, we soon shall right all wrong,
And send some headless from the court ere long.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

stagedir.dir: Trumpets sound. Enter King Richard, Green, Bagot, Bushy, Scroop, Tresilian, and others.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thus shall King Richard suit his princely train
Despite his uncles’ pride. Embrace us, gentlemen.
Sir Edward Bagot, Bushy, Green, and Scroop,
Your youths are fitting to our tender years,
And such shall beautify our princely throne.
Fear not my uncles, nor their proudest strength,
For I will buckler ye against them all.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Thanks, dearest lord. Let me have Richard’s love,
And like a rock unmov’d my state shall stand,
Scorning the proudest peer that rules the land.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Your uncles seeks to overturn your state,
To awe ye like a child, that they alone
May at their pleasures thrust you from the throne.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: As if the sun were forced to decline
Before his dated time of darkness comes.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Sweet King, set courage to authority,
And let them know the power of majesty.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: May not the lion roar because he’s young?
What are your uncles but as elephants
That set their aged bodies to the oak?
You are the oak against whose stock they lean:
Fall from them once, and then destroy them ever.
Be thou no stay, King Richard, to their strength
But as a tyrant unto tyranny,
And so confound them all eternally.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Law must extend unto severity
When subjects dare to brave their sovereign.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Tresilian, thou art Lord Chief Justice now,
Who should be learned in the laws but thee?
Resolve us therefore what thou think’st of them
That under title of protectorship
Seek to subvert their king and sovereign.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: As of the King’s rebellious enemies,
As underminers of his sacred state,
Which in the greatest prince or mightiest peer
That is a subject to your Majesty
Is nothing less than treason capital,
And he a traitor that endeavors it.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Attaint them then, arrest them and condemn them!

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Hale them to th’ block and cut off all their heads,
And then, King Richard, claim the government!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: See it be done, Tresilian, speedily.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: That course is all too rash, my gracious lord.

speech.speaker: ALL. FAV.
speech.line: Too rash for what?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: It must be done with greater policy
For fear the people rise in mutiny.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ay, there’s the fear the commons love them well,
And all applaud the wily Lancaster,
The counterfeit relenting Duke of York,
Together with our fretful uncle Woodstock,
With greater reverence than King Richard’s self.
But time shall come when we shall yoke their necks
And make them bend to our obedience.
How now, what read’st thou, Bushy?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: The monument of English Chronicles, my lord,
Containing acts and memorable deeds
Of all your famous predecessor kings.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What find’st thou of them?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Examples strange and wonderful, my lord,
The end of treason even in mighty persons:
For here ’tis said your royal grandfather,
Although but young and under government,
Took the Protector then, proud Mortimer,
And on a gallows fifty-foot in height
He hung him for his pride and treachery.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why should our proud Protector then presume
And we not punish him, whose treason’s viler far
Than ever was rebellious Mortimer’s ?
Prithee, read on: examples such as these
Will bring us to our kingly grandsire’s spirit.
What’s next?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: The battle full of dread and doubtful fear
Was fought betwixt your father and the French.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Read on, we’ll hear it.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Then the Black Prince, encouraging his soldiers, being in number but 7,750, gave the onset to the French king’s puissant army, which were number’d to 68,000, and in one hour got the victory, slew 6,000 of the French soldiers, took prisoners of dukes, earls, knights and gentlemen to the number 1,700 and of the common sort 10,000; so the prisoners that were taken were twice so many as the Englishmen were in number. Besides, the thrice-renowned prince took with his own hand King John of France and his son prisoners. This was call’d the Battle of Poitiers, and was fought on Monday the nineteenth of September, 1363, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: A victory most strange and admirable.
Never was conquest got with such great odds.
Oh, princely Edward, had thy son such hap,
Such fortune and success to follow him,
His daring uncles and rebellious peers
Durst not control and govern as they do.
But these bright shining trophies shall awake me,
And, as we are his body’s counterfeit,
So will we be the image of his mind,
And die but we’ll attain his virtuous deeds.
What next ensues? Good Bushy, read the rest.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Here is set down, my princely sovereign,
The certain time and day when you were born.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Our birthday, say’st thou? Is that noted there?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: It is, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Prithee, let me hear’t,
For thereby hangs a secret mystery
Which yet our uncle strangely keeps from us.
On, Bushy.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Upon the third of April, 1365, was Lord Richard, son to the Black Prince, born at Bordeaux.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Stay, let me think awhile. Read it again.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Upon the third of April, 1365, was Lord Richard, son to the Black
Prince, born at Bordeaux.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thirteen sixty-five? What year is this?

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: ’Tis now, my lord, 1387.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: By that account, the third of April next
Our age is number’d two-and-twenty years.
Oh, treacherous men that have deluded us,
We might have claim’d our right a twelve-month since!
Shut up thy book, good Bushy. Bagot, Green,
King Richard in his throne will now be seen.

stagedir.dir: A knock within. Bagot to the door.

speech.line: This day I’ll claim my right, my kingdom’s due.
Our uncles well shall know they but intrude,
For which we’ll smite their base ingratitude.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York, my lord,
Sent from the Lord Protector and the peers,
Doth crave admittance to your royal presence.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Our uncle Edmund. So. Were it not he,
We would not speak with him; but go, admit him.
Woodstock and Gaunt are stern and troublesome,
But York is gentle, mild and generous,
And therefore we admit his conference.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: He comes, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Methinks ’tis strange, my good and reverend uncle,
You and the rest should thus malign against us,
And every hour with rude and bitter taunts
Abuse King Richard and his harmless friends.
We had a father that once call’d ye brother,
A grandsire too that titled you his son,
But could they see how you have wrong’d King Richard,
Their ghosts would haunt ye, and in dead of night
Fright all your quiet sleeps with horrid fears.
I pray, stand up, we honor reverend years
In meaner subjects. Good uncle, rise and tell us:
What further mischiefs are there now devis’d
To torture and afflict your sovereign with?

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: My royal lord, even by my birth I swear,
My father’s tomb, and faith to heaven I owe,
Your uncles’ thoughts are all most honorable.
And to that end the good Protector sends me
To certify your sacred Majesty
The peers of England now are all assembled
To hold a parliament at Westminster,
And humbly crave your Highness would be there
To sit in council touching such affairs
As shall concern your country’s government.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Have they so soon procur’d a parliament?
Without our knowledge too? ’Tis somewhat strange.
Yet say, good uncle, we will meet them straight.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: The news to all will be most wish’d and welcome.
I take my leave, and to your Grace I swear
As I am subject loyal, just and true,
We’ll nothing do to hurt the realm nor you.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We shall believe you, uncle.
Go, attend him.
Yes, we will meet them, but with such intent
As shall dismiss their sudden parliament
Till we be pleas’d to summon and direct it.
Come, sirs, to Westminster, attend our state,
This day shall make you ever fortunate.
The third of AprilBushy, note the time
Our age accomplish’d, crown and kingdom’s mine.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York
John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

stagedir.dir: Flourish of trumpets. Enter Queen Anne, the Duchess of Ireland, the Duchess of Gloucester, Woodstock with petitions and the Mace, and Sir Thomas Cheney. Enter Lancaster, Arundel and Surrey. The Duke of York meets them in haste.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Now, brother York, what says King Richard, ha?

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: His Highness will be here immediately.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Go, cousin Surrey, greet the parliament,
Tell them the King is coming, give these petitions
To th’ knights and burgesses o’ the lower house,
Sent from each several shire of all the kingdom.
These copies I will keep and show his Highness.
Pray make haste.

speech.speaker: SUR.
speech.line: I will, my lord.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Pity King Richard’s youth, most reverend uncles,
And in your high proceedings gently use him.
Think of his tender years; what’s now amiss
His riper judgment shall make good and perfect
To you and to the kingdom’s benefit.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Alack, sweet queen, you and our lord the King
Have little cause to fear our just proceedings.
We’ll fall beneath his feet and bend our knees,
So he cast off those hateful flatterers
That daily ruinate his state and kingdom.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Go in, sweet ladies, comfort one another.
This happy parliament shall make all even,
And plant sure peace betwixt the King and realm.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: May heaven direct your wisdoms to provide
For England’s honor and King Richard’s good.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Believe no less, sweet queen. Attend her Highness.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Queen Anne and the Duchesses of Gloucester and Ireland.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: The King is come, my lords.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Stand from the door, then. Make way, Cheney.

stagedir.dir: Sound a flourish. Enter King Richard, Bagot, Bushy, Green, Scroop, and others.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Yonder’s your uncles, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ay, with our plain Protector,
Full of complaints, sweet Green, I’ll wage my crown.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Give them fair words and smooth awhile:
The toils are pitch’d, and you may catch them quickly.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why, how now, uncle! What, disrob’d again
Of all your golden rich habiliments?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ay, ay, good coz, I’m now in my t’other hose,
I’m now myself, Plain Thomas, and by th’ rood
In these plain hose I’ll do the realm more good
Than these that pill the poor to jet in gold.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Nay, be not angry, uncle.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Be you then pleas’d, good coz, to hear me speak,
And view thy subjects’ sad petitions.
See here, King Richard, whilst thou livest at ease
Lulling thyself in nice security,
Thy wronged kingdom’s in a mutiny.
From every province are the people come,
With open mouths exclaiming on the wrongs
Thou and these upstarts have impos’d on them.
Shame is decipher’d on thy palace gate,
Confusion hangeth o’er thy wretched head,
Mischief is coming and in storms must fall:
Th’ oppression of the poor to heaven doth call.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Well, well, good uncle, these your bitter taunts
Against my friends and me will one day cease.
But what’s the reason you have sent for us?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: To have your Grace confirm this parliament
And set your hand to certain articles
Most needful for your state and kingdom’s quiet.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Where are those articles?

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: The states and burgesses o’ th’ parliament
Attend with duty to deliver them.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Please you ascend your throne, we’ll call them in.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We’ll ask a question first, and then we’ll see them;
For trust me, reverend uncles, we have sworn
We will not sit upon our royal throne
Until this question be resolv’d at full.
Reach me that paper, Bushy. Hear me, princes:
We had a strange petition here deliver’d us.
A poor man’s son, his father being deceas’d,
Gave him in charge unto a rich man’s hands
To keep him and the little land he had
Till he attain’d to one-and-twenty years.
The poor revenue amounts but to three crowns,
And yet th’ insatiate churl denies his right
And bars him of his fair inheritance.
Tell me, I pray: will not our English laws
Enforce this rich man to resign his due?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: There is no let to bar it, gracious sovereign.
Afore my God, sweet prince, it joys my soul
To see your Grace in person thus to judge his cause.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Such deeds as this will make King Richard shine
Above his famous predecessor kings
If thus he labor to establish right.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: The poor man then had wrong, you all confess?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: And shall have right, my liege, to quit his wrong!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then, Woodstock, give us right, for we are wrong’d.
Thou art the rich, and we the poor man’s son.
The realms of England, France, and Ireland
Are those three crowns thou yearly keep’st from us.
Is’t not a wrong when every mean man’s son
May take his birthright at the time expir’d,
And we, the principal, being now attain’d
Almost to two-and-twenty years of age,
Cannot be suffer’d to enjoy our own,
Nor peaceably possess our father’s right?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Was this the trick, sweet prince? Alack the day,
You need not thus have doubled with your friends.
The right I hold, even with my heart I render,
And wish your Grace had claim’d it long ago
Thou’dst rid mine age of mickle care and woe.
And yet I think I have not wrong’d your birthright,
For if the times were search’d I guess your Grace
Is not so full of years till April next.
But be it as it will. Lo, here, King Richard,
I thus yield up my sad protectorship.
A heavy burden hast thou ta’en from me.
Long may’st thou live in peace and keep thine own,
That truth and justice may attend thy throne.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then in the name of heaven we thus ascend it,
And here we claim our fair inheritance
Of fruitful England, France, and Ireland,
Superior Lord of Scotland, and the rights
Belonging to our great dominions.
Here, uncles, take the crown from Richard’s hand
And once more place it on our kingly head:
This day we will be new enthronished.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: With all our hearts, my lord. Trumpets, be ready.

speech.speaker: ALL. IN PARL.
speech.line: Long live King Richard, of that name the second,
The sovereign lord of England’s ancient rights!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We thank ye all.
So. Now we feel ourself.
Our body could not fill this chair till now,
’Twas scanted to us by protectorship.
But now we let ye know King Richard rules
And will elect and choose, place and displace,
Such officers as we ourself shall like of.
And first, my lords, because your age is such
As pity ’twere ye should be further press’d
With weighty business of the common weal,
We here dismiss ye from the council table
And will that you remain not in our court.
Deliver up your staves; and hear ye, Arundel,
We do discharge ye of the Admiralty.
Scroop, take his office and his place in Council.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: I thank your Highness.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Here, take my staff, good cousin. York thus leaves thee.
Thou lean’st on staves that will at length deceive thee.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: There lie the burden of old Lancaster,
And may he perish that succeeds my place!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: So, sir, we will observe your humor.
Sir Henry Green, succeed our uncle York;
And Bushy, take the staff of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: I thank your Grace: his curses frights not me.
I’ll keep it to defend your Majesty.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: What transformation do mine eyes behold,
As if the world were topsy-turvy turn’d!
Hear me, King Richard!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Plain Thomas, I’ll not hear ye.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Ye do not well to move his Majesty.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Hence, flatterer, or by my soul I’ll kill thee!
Shall England, that so long was governed
By grave experience of white-headed age,
Be subject now to rash unskillful boys?
Then force the sun run backward to the east,
Lay Atlas’ burden on a pigmy’s back,
Appoint the sea his times to ebb and flow
And that as easily may be done as this!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Give up your Council staff, we’ll hear no more.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: My staff, King Richard? See, coz, here it is.
Full ten years’ space within a prince’s hand,
A soldier and a faithful councilor,
This staff hath always been discreetly kept;
Nor shall the world report an upstart groom
Did glory in the honors Woodstock lost.
And therefore, Richard, thus I sever it.
There, let him take it, shiver’d, crack’d and broke,
As will the state of England be ere long
By thus rejecting true nobility.
Farewell, King Richard. I’ll to Plashy, brothers;
If ye ride through Essex, call and see me.
If once the pillars and supporters quail,
How can the strongest castle choose but fail?

speech.speaker: LORDS.
speech.line: And so will he ere long. Come, come, let’s leave them.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Ay, ay, your places are supplied sufficiently.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt the Lords (Woodstock, Cheney, Lancaster, York, Arundel).

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: Old doting graybeards!
’Fore God, my lord, had they not been your uncles,
I’d broke my Council staff about their heads.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: We’ll have an Act for this: it shall be henceforth counted high treason for any fellow with a gray beard to come within forty foot of the court gates!

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Ay, or a great-bellied doublet. We’ll alter the kingdom presently.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Pox on’t, we’ll not have a beard amongst us. We’ll shave the country and the city too, shall we not, Richard?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Do what ye will, we’ll shield and buckler ye.
We’ll have a guard of archers to attend us,
And they shall daily wait on us and you.
Send proclamations straight in Richard’s name
T’abridge the laws our late Protector made.
Let some be sent to seek Tresilian forth.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Seek him? Hang him! He lurks not far off, I warrant. And this news come abroad once, ye shall have him here presently.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Would he were come! His counsel would direct you well.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Troth, I think I shall trouble myself but with a few counselors. What cheer shall we have to dinner, King Richard?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: No matter what, today. We’ll mend it shortly.
The hall at Westminster shall be enlarg’d,
And only serve us for a dining room
Wherein I’ll daily feast ten thousand men.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: An excellent device! The commons has murmur’d against us a great while, and there’s no such means as meat to stop their mouths.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, make their gate wider! Let’s first filch their money and bid them to dinner afterwards.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: ’Sblood, and I were not a Councilor, I could find in my heart to dine at a tavern today. Sweet king, shall’s be merry?

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: We must have money to buy new suits, my lord. The fashions that we wear are gross and stale. We’ll go sit in Council to devise some new.

speech.speaker: ALL. FAV.
speech.line: A special purpose to be thought upon! It shall be the first thing we’ll do!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Come, wantons, come. If Gloucester hear of this,
He’ll say our Council guides us much amiss.
Dismiss the parliament our uncles call’d,
And tell the peers it is our present pleasure
That each man parts unto his several home.
When we are pleas’d, they shall have summons sent
And with King Richard hold a parliament.
Set forward.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: You of the Council, march before the king;
I will support his arm.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Gramercy, Green.

stagedir.dir: Trumpets sound a flourish. Exeunt omnes.
Enter Queen Anne, the Duchess of Gloucester, the Duchess of Ireland, and maids with shirts and bands and other linen.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Tell me, dear aunt, has Richard so forgot
The types of honor and nobility
So to disgrace his good and virtuous uncles?

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Madam, ’tis true. No sooner had he claim’d
The full possession of his government,
But my dear husband and his noble brethren
Were all dismissed from the Council table,
Banish’d the court, and even before their faces
Their offices bestow’d on several grooms.

speech.speaker: DUCH. IRE.
speech.line: My husband, Ireland, that unloving lord
(God pardon his amiss, he now is dead)
King Richard was the cause he left my bed.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: No more, good cousin. Could I work the means,
He should not so disgrace his dearest friends.
Alack the day! Though I am England’s queen,
I meet sad hours and wake when others sleep.
He meets content, but care with me must keep.
Distressed poverty o’erspreads the kingdom:
In Essex, Surrey, Kent and Middlesex
Are seventeen thousand poor and indigent
Which I have number’d; and, to help their wants,
My jewels and my plate are turn’d to coin
And shar’d amongst them. Oh, riotous Richard,
A heavy blame is thine for this distress,
That dost allow thy polling flatterers
To gild themselves with others’ miseries.

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Wrong not yourself with sorrow, gentle queen,
Unless that sorrow were a helping means
To cure the malady you sorrow for.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: The sighs I vent are not mine own, dear aunt.
I do not sorrow in mine own behalf,
Nor now repent with peevish frowardness
And wish I ne’er had seen this English shore,
But think me happy in King Richard’s love.
No, no, good aunt, this troubles not my soul:
’Tis England’s subjects’ sorrow I sustain.
I fear they grudge against their sovereign.

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Fear not that, madam, England’s not mutinous;
’Tis peopled all with subjects, not with outlaws.
Though Richard, much misled by flatterers,
Neglects, and throws his scepter carelessly,
Yet none dares rob him of his kingly rule.

speech.speaker: DUCH. IRE.
speech.line: Besides, your virtuous charity, fair Queen,
So graciously hath won the commons’ love,
As only you have power to stay their rigor.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: The wealth I have shall be the poor’s revenue
As sure as ’twere confirm’d by parliament.
This mine own industry (and sixty more
I daily keep at work) is all their own.
The coin I have, I send them; would ’twere more!
To satisfy my fears, or pay those sums
My wanton lord hath forc’d from needy subjects,
I’d want myself. Go, let those trunks be fill’d
With those our labors to relieve the poor.
Let them be carefully distributed.
For those that now shall want, we’ll work again,
And tell them ere two days they shall be furnish’d.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: What, is the court removing? Whither goes that trunk?

speech.speaker: 1. MAID.
speech.line: ’Tis the queen’s charity, sir, of needful clothing
To be distributed amongst the poor.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Why, there’s one blessing yet, that England hath
A virtuous queen, although a wanton king.
Good health, sweet princess! Believe me, madam,
You have quick utterance for your huswifery.
Your Grace affords good pennyworths, sure, ye sell so fast!
Pray heaven your gettings quit your swift return.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Amen, for ’tis from heaven I look for recompense.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: No doubt, fair queen, the righteous powers will quit you
For these religious deeds of charity.
But to my message:
Madam, my lord the Duke
Entreats your Grace prepare with him to horse.
He will this night ride home to Plashy House.

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Madam, ye hear I’m sent for.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Then begone:
Leave me alone in desolation.

speech.speaker: DUCH. IRE.
speech.line: Adieu, good aunt, I’ll see ye shortly there:
King Richard’s kindred are not welcome here.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Will ye all leave me, then? Oh, woe is me,
I now am crown’d a queen of misery.

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Where did’st thou leave my husband, Cheney? Speak.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Accompanied with the Dukes of York and Lancaster
Who, as I guess, intends to ride with him,
For which he wish’d me haste your Grace’s presence.

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Thou see’st the passions of the Queen are such
I may not too abruptly leave her Highness;
But tell my lord I’ll see him presently.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Saw’st thou King Richard, Cheney? Prithee, tell me,
What revels keeps his flattering minions?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: They sit in Council to devise strange fashions,
And suit themselves in wild and antic habits
Such as this kingdom never yet beheld:
French hose, Italian cloaks, and Spanish hats,
Polonian shoes with peaks a handful long,
Tied to their knees with chains of pearl and gold.
Their plumed tops fly waving in the air
A cubit high above their wanton heads.
Tresilian with King Richard likewise sits
Devising taxes and strange shifts for money
To build again the hall at Westminster
To feast and revel in; and when abroad they come,
Four hundred archers in a guard attends them.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Oh, certain ruin of this famous kingdom!
Fond Richard, thou build’st a hall to feast in
And starvest thy wretched subjects to erect it!
Woe to those men that thus incline thy soul
To these remorseless acts and deeds so foul!

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: The trumpets tell us that King Richard’s coming.
I’ll take my leave, fair queen, but credit me,
Ere many days again I’ll visit ye.

speech.speaker: DUCH. IRE.
speech.line: I’ll home to Langley with my uncle York,
And there lament alone my wretched state.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Bless’d heaven conduct ye both. Queen Anne alone
For Richard’s follies still must sigh and groan.

stagedir.dir: Sound a sennet. Enter King Richard, Bagot, Bushy, Green, Scroop, very richly attired in new fashions; and Tresilian with blank charters whispering with the King, a guard of archers after them.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Come, my Tresilian.
Thus like an emperor shall King Richard reign,
And you so many kings attendant on him.
Our guard of archers, keep the doors, I charge ye,
Let no man enter to disturb our pleasures.
Thou told’st me, kind Tresilian, th’ad’st devis’d
Blank Charters to fill up our treasury,
Opening the chests of hoarding cormorants
That laugh to see their kingly sovereign lack.
Let’s know the means we may applaud thy wit.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: See here, my lord: only with parchment, innocent sheepskins. Ye see here’s no fraud, no clause, no deceit in the writing.

speech.speaker: ALL. FAV.
speech.line: Why, there’s nothing writ!

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: There’s the trick on’t!
These Blank Charters shall be forthwith sent
To every shrieve through all the shires of England,
With charge to call before them presently
All landed men, freeholders, farmers, graziers,
Or any else that have ability.
Then in your Highness’ name they shall be charg’d
To set their names and forthwith seal these Blanks.
That done, these shall return to court again,
But cartloads of money soon shall follow them.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: Excellent, Tresilian!

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Noble Lord Chief Justice!

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Where should his Grace get such a Councilor!

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Not if his beard were off! Prithee, Tresilian, off with it! ’Sfoot, thou see’st we have not a beard amongst us! Thou send’st out barbers there to poll the whole country; ’sfoot, let some shave thee!

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: ’Twould become thee better, i’faith, and make thee look more grim when thou sit’st in judgment.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: I tell ye, gallants, I will not lose a hair for my lordships’ and King Richard’s favor or the Pope’s revenues!

speech.speaker: GUARD.
speech.line: By your leave there, give way to the Queen!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Now, Anne a’ Beame, how cheers my dearest queen?
Is’t holiday, my love? Believe me, lords,
’Tis strange to take her from her sempstery,
She and her maids are all for housewif’ry.
Shalt work no more, sweet Nan, now Richard’s king,
And peer and people all shall stoop to him.
We’ll have no more protecting uncles, trust me!
Prithee, look smooth and bid these nobles welcome.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Whom my lord favors must to me be welcome.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: These are our Councilors, I tell ye, lady,
And these shall better grace King Richard’s court
Than all the doting heads that late controll’d us.
Thou see’st already we begin to alter
The vulgar fashions of our homespun kingdom.
I tell thee, Nan, the states of Christendom
Shall wonder at our English royalty.
We held a Council to devise these suits:
Sir Henry Green devis’d this fashion shoe,
Bushy this peak; Bagot and Scroop set forth
This kind coherence ’twixt the toe and knee
To have them chain’d together lovingly;
And we, as sovereign, did confirm them all.
Suit they not quaintly, Nan? Sweet queen, resolve me.

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: I see no fault that I dare call a fault.
But would your Grace consider with advice
What you have done unto your reverend uncles?
My fears provoke me to be bold, my lord:
They are your noble kinsmen, to revoke
The sentence were

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: An act of folly, Nan!
Kings’ words are laws: if we infringe our word,
We break our law. No more of them, sweet queen.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Madam, what’s done was with advice enough:
The King is now at years and hath shook off
The servile yoke of mean protectorship.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: His Highness can direct himself sufficient.
Why should his pleasures then be curb’d by any,
As if he did not understand his state?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: They tell thee true, sweet love. Come, ride with me
And see today my hall at Westminster,
Which we have builded now to feast our friends.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Do, do, good madam. Prithee, sweet king, let’s ride somewhither and it be but to show ourselves. ’Sfoot, our devices here are like jewels kept in caskets, or good faces in masks that grace not the owners because they’re obscur’d. If our fashions be not publish’d, what glory’s in the wearing?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We’ll ride through London only to be gaz’d at.
Fair Anne a’ Beame, you shall along with us;
At Westminster shalt see my sumptuous hall,
My royal tables richly furnished
Where every day I feast ten thousand men,
To furnish out which feast I daily spend
Thirty fat oxen and three hundred sheep,
With fish and fowl in numbers numberless.
Not all our chronicles shall point a king
To match our bounty, state, and royalty.
Or let all our successors yet to come
Strive to exceed me, and if they forbid it,
Let records say, only King Richard did it!

speech.speaker: QUEEN.
speech.line: Oh, but my lord, ’twill tire your revenues
To keep this festival a year together!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: As many days as I write ‘England’s King,’
We will maintain that bounteous festival.
Tresilian, look to your Blank Charters speedily,
Send them abroad with trusty officers.
And Bagot, see a messenger be sent
To call our uncle Woodstock home to th’ court.
Not that we love his meddling company,
But that the ragged commons loves his plainness,
And should grow mutinous about these Blanks,
We’ll have him near us. Within his arrow’s length
We stand secure: we can restrain his strength.
See it be done. Come, Anne, to our great hall,
Where Richard keeps his gorgeous festival.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Within there, ho!

speech.speaker: CROS.
speech.line: Your lordship’s pleasure?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: What, are those Blanks dispatch’d?

speech.speaker: FLEM.
speech.line: They’re all truss’d up, my lord, in several packets.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Where’s Nimble? Where’s that varlet?

stagedir.dir: Enter Nimble in peaked shoes with knee-chains.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: As nimble as a morris-dancer, now my bells are on.
How do ye like the rattling of my chains, my lord?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Oh, villain, thou wilt hang in chains for this.
Art thou crept into the court fashion, knave?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Alas, my lord, ye know I have follow’d your lordship without e’er a rag since ye ran away from the court once; and I pray let me follow the fashion a little, to show myself a courtier.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Go, spread those several Blanks throughout the kingdom,
And here’s commission with the Council’s hands
With charge to every shrieve and officer
T’assist and aid you. And when they’re seal’d and sign’d,
See ye note well such men’s ability
As set their hands to them. Inquire what rents,
What lands, or what revenues they spend by th’ year,
And let me straight receive intelligence.
Besides, I’d have you use yourselves so cunningly
To mark who grudges or but speaks amiss
Of good King Richard, myself, or any of his new Councilors.
Attach them all for privy whisperers
And send them up. I have a trick in law
Shall make King Richard seize into his hands
The forfeiture of all their goods and lands.
Nimble, take thou these Blanks, and see
You take especial note of them.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I’ll take the ditty, sir, but you shall set a note to’t, for if any man shall speak but an ill word of anything that’s written here

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Why, ass, there’s nothing.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: And would ye have them speak ill of nothing? That’s strange! But I mean, my lord, if they should but give this paper an ill word, as to say, ‘I will tear this paper,’ or worse, ‘I will rend this paper,’ or fouler words than that, as to say, ‘I will bumfiddle your paper,’if there be any such, I have a black book for them, my lord, I warrant ye.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Be it your greatest care to be severe.
Crosby and Fleming, pray be diligent.

speech.speaker: CROS.
speech.line: We shall, my lord.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: But how if we meet with some ignoramus fellows, my lord, that cannot write their minds? What shall they do?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: If they but set to their marks, ’tis good.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: We shall meddle with no women in the Blanks, shall we?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Rich widows, none else; for a widow is as much as man and wife.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Then a widow’s a hermaphrodite, both cut and long-tail, and if she cannot write, she shall set her mark to it.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: What else, sir?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: But if she have a daughter, she shall set her mother’s mark to’t?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Meddle with none but men and widows, sir, I charge ye.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Well, sir, I shall see a widow’s mark, then: I ne’er saw none yet!

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: You have your lessons perfect, now begone:
Be bold and swift in execution.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Goodbye, my lord. We will domineer over the vulgar like so many Saint Georges over the poor dragons. Come, sirs, we are like to have a flourishing common-wealth, i’ faith!

scenepersonae.scenepersona: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster
Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Come, my good brothers, here at Plashy House
I’ll bid you welcome with as true a heart
As Richard with a false, and mind corrupt,
Disgrac’d our names and thrust us from his court.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Beshrew him that repines, my lord, for me,
I liv’d with care at court, I now am free.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Come, come, let’s find some other talk. I think not on it.
I ne’er slept soundly when I was amongst them,
So let them go. This house of Plashy, brother,
Stands in a sweet and pleasant air, i’ faith.
’Tis near the Thames and circled round with trees
That in the summer serve for pleasant fans
To cool ye, and in winter strongly break
The stormy winds that else would nip ye too.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: And in faith, old York,
We have all need of some kind wintering:
We are beset, heaven shield, with many storms.
And yet these trees at length will prove to be
Like Richard and his riotous minions:
Their wanton heads so oft play with the winds
Throwing their leaves so prodigally down,
They’ll leave me cold at last. And so will they
Make England wretched and, i’ th’ end, themselves.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: If Westminster Hall devour as it has begun,
’Twere better it were ruin’d lime and stone.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Afore my God, I late was certified
That at one feast was serv’d ten thousand dishes.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: He daily feasts, they say, ten thousand men,
And every man must have his dish, at least.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Thirty fat oxen and three hundred sheep
Serve but one day’s expenses.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: A hundred scarcely can suffice his guard;
A camp of soldiers feeds not like those bowmen.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: But how will these expenses be maintain’d?

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Oh, they say there are strange tricks come forth
To fetch in money. What they are, I know not.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: You’ve heard of the fantastic suits they wear?
Never was English king so habited.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: We could allow his clothing, brother Woodstock,
But we have four kings more, are equal’d with him:
There’s Bagot, Bushy, wanton Green, and Scroop,
In state and fashion without difference.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Indeed, they’re more than kings, for they rule him.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Come, come, our breaths reverberate the wind.
We talk like good divines, but cannot cure
The grossness of the sin. Or shall we speak
Like all-commanding wise astronomers
And flatly say, such a day shall be fair,
And yet it rains, whether he will or no?
So may we talk, but thus will Richard do.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: How now, Cheney, what drives thee on so fast?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: If I durst, I would say, my lord,
Tresilian drives me on haste so ill:
I’m still the pursuivant of unhappy news.
Here’s blank charters, my lord, I pray behold them,
Sent from King Richard and his Councilors.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Thou mak’st me blank at very sight of them!
What may these—?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: They appear in shape of obligations.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: They are no less. The country’s full of them.
Commissions are come down to every shrieve
To force the richest subjects of the land
To set their hands and forthwith seal these blanks
That shall confirm a due debt to the King,
And then the bond must afterwards be paid
As much or little as they please to ’point it.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Oh, strange, unheard-of, vile taxation!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Who is’t can help my memory a little?
Has not this e’er been held a principle:
‘There’s nothing spoke or done that has not been’ ?

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: It was a maxim ere I had a beard.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: ’Tis now found false, an open heresy:
This is a thing was never spoke nor done!
Blank Charters call ye them? If any age
Keep but a record of this policy
I phrase it too, too well, flat villainy
Let me be chronicl’d Apostata,
Rebellious to my God and country both!

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: How do the people entertain these Blanks?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: With much dislike, yet some for fear have sign’d them.
Others there be refuse and murmur strangely.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Afore my God, I cannot blame them for it:
He might as well have sent defiance to them.
Oh, vulture England, wilt thou eat thine own?
Can they be rebels call’d, that now turn head?
I speak but what I fear, not what I wish.
This foul oppression will withdraw all duty,
And in the commons’ hearts hot rancors breed
To make our country’s bosom shortly bleed.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: What shall we do to seek for remedy?

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Let each man hie him to his several home
Before the people rise in mutiny,
And in the mildest part of lenity
Seek to restrain them from rebellion
For what can else be look’d for? Promise redress;
That eloquence is best in this distress.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: York counsels well. Let’s haste away.
The time is sick, we must not use delay.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Let’s still confer by letters.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Content, content,
So friends may parley even in banishment.
Farewell, good brothers! Cheney, conduct them forth.
Adieu, good York and Gaunt, farewell forever.
I have a sad presage comes suddenly
That I shall never see these brothers more.
On earth, I fear, we never more shall meet.
Of Edward the Third’s seven sons we three are left
To see our father’s kingdom ruinate.
I would my death might end the misery
My fear presageth to my wretched country.
The commons will rebel, without all question,
And, ’fore my God, I have no eloquence
To stay this uproar. I must tell them plain,
We all are struck but must not strike again.
How now? What news?

speech.speaker: SERV. WOOD.
speech.line: There’s a horseman at the gate, my lord.
He comes from the King, he says, to see your Grace.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: To see me, say’st thou? A’ God’s name, let him come,
