So he brings no Blank Charters with him!
Prithee, bid him ’light and enter.

speech.speaker: SERV. WOOD.
speech.line: I think he dares not for fouling on his feet, my lord. I would have had him ’light, but he swears as he’s a courtier he will not off on’s horse’ back till the inner gate be open.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Passion of me, that’s strange! I prithee, give him satisfaction, open the inner gate. What might this fellow be?

speech.speaker: SERV. WOOD.
speech.line: Some fine fool: he’s attir’d very fantastically, and talks as foolishly.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Go, let him in, and when you have done, bid Cheney come and speak with me.

speech.speaker: SERV. WOOD.
speech.line: I will, my lord. Come on, sir, ye may ride into my lord’s cellar now, and ye will, sir.

stagedir.dir: Enter a Spruce Courtier on horseback.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: Prithee, fellow, stay and take my horse.

speech.speaker: SERV. WOOD.
speech.line: I have business for my lord, sir, I cannot.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: A rude swain, by heaven! But stay, here walks another. Hear’st-ta thou, fellow, is this Plashy House?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ye should have ask’d that question before ye came in, sir. But this is it.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: The hinds are all most rude and gross. I prithee, walk my horse.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: I have a little business, sir.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: Thou shalt not lose by’t. I’ll give thee a tester for thy pains.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: I shall be glad to earn money, sir.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: Prithee, do, and know thy duty. Thy head’s too saucy.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Cry ye mercy, I did not understand your worship’s calling!

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: The Duke of Gloucester lies here, does he not?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Marry, does he, sir.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: Is he within?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: He’s not far off, sir, he was here even now.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: Ah, very good. Walk my horse well, I prithee, h’as travel’d hard and he’s hot, i’ faith.
I’ll in and speak with the Duke, and pay thee presently.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: I make no doubt, sir.

Oh, strange metamorphosis! Is’t possible that this fellow that’s all made of fashions should be an Englishman? No marvel if he know not me, being so brave, and I so beggarly! Well, I shall earn money to enrich me now and ’tis the first I earn’d, by the rood, this forty year.

Come on, sir, you have sweat hard about this haste, yet I think you know little of the business. Why so I say? You’re a very indifferent beast, you’ll follow any man that will lead you. Now truly, sir, you look but e’en leanly on it. You feed not in Westminster Hall ’a-days, where so many sheep and oxen are devour’d. I’m afraid they’ll eat you shortly, if you tarry amongst them. You’re prick’d more with the spur than the provender, I see that. I think your dwelling be at Hackney when you are at home, is’t not? You know not the Duke neither, no more than your master, and yet I think you have as much wit as he, i’ faith! Say a man should steal ye and feed ye fatter, could ye run away with him lustily? Ah, your silence argues a consent, I see! By the Mass, here comes company. We had been both taken if we had, I see.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Saw ye not my lord at the gate, say ye? Why, I left him there but now.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: In sooth, I saw no creature, sir, only an old groom I got to walk my horse.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: A groom, say ye! ’Sfoot, ’tis my lord, the Duke! What have ye done? This is somewhat too coarse, your Grace should be an ostler to this fellow!

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: I do beseech your Grace’s pardon. The error was in the mistake that your plainness did deceive me. Please it your Grace to redeliver.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: No, by my faith, I’ll have my money first. Promise is a debt.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: I know your Grace’s goodness will refuse it.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Think not so nicely of me; indeed, I will not.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: If so you please, there is your tester.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: If so you please, there is your horse, sir.
Now pray you tell me, is your haste to me?

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: Most swift and serious from His Majesty.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: What, from King Richard, my dear lord and kinsman? Go, sirrah, take you his horse, lead him to the stable, meat him well, I’ll double his reward. There’s twelve pence for ye.

speech.speaker: SERV. WOOD.
speech.line: I thank your Grace.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Now, sir, your business.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: His Majesty commends him to your Grace.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: This same’s a rare fashion you have got at court. Of whose devising was’t, I pray?

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: I assure your Grace, King Richard’s council sat three days about it.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: By my faith, their wisdoms took great pains, I assure ye! The state was well employ’d the whiles, by th’ rood. Then this at court is all the fashion now?

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: The King himself doth wear it, whose most gracious Majesty sent me in haste.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: This peak doth strangely well become the foot.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: This peak the King doth likewise wear, being a Polonian peak; and me did his Highness pick from forth the rest.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: He could not have pick’d out such another, I assure ye.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: I thank your Grace that picks me out so well;
But, as I said, his Highness would request

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: But this most fashionable chain, that links as it were the toe and knee together?

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: In a most kind coherence, so it like your Grace. For these two parts, being in operation and quality different, as for example, the toe a disdainer or spurner, the knee a dutiful and most humble orator, this chain doth, as it were, so toeify the knee and so kneeify the toe, that between both it makes a most methodical coherence, or coherent method.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: ’Tis most excellent, sir, and full of art. Please ye, walk in.

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: My message tender’d, I will tend your Grace.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Cry ye mercy, have you a message to me?

speech.speaker: COURT.
speech.line: His Majesty, most affectionately, and like a royal kinsman, entreats your Grace’s presence at the court.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Is that your message, sir? I must refuse it, then.
My English plainness will not suit that place,
The court’s too fine for me. My service here
Will stand in better stead, to quench the fire
Those Blanks have made. I would they were all burnt,
Or he were hang’d that first devis’d them, sir,
They stir the country so. I dare not come,
And so excuse me, sir. If the King think it ill,
He thinks amiss; I am Plain Thomas still.
The rest I’ll tell ye as ye sit at meat.
Furnish a table, Cheney, call for wine.
Come, sir, ye shall commend me to the King!
Tell him I’ll keep these parts in peace to him.

stagedir.dir: Enter Master Ignorance, the Bailey of Dunstable, Crosby, Fleming, and Nimble, with blank charters. Officers with bills in attendance.

speech.speaker: CROS.
speech.line: Despatch, good Master Bailey, the market’s almost done, you see. ’Tis rumor’d that the Blanks are come and the rich chuffs begin to flock out o’ the town already. You have seen the High Shrieve’s warrant and the Council’s commis-sion, and therefore I charge ye in the king’s name, be ready to assist us.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Nay, look ye, sir, be not too pestiferous, I beseech ye. I have begun myself and seal’d one of your Blanks already, and by my example there’s more shall follow. I know my place and calling, my name is Ignorance and I am Bailey of Dunstable. I cannot write nor read, I confess it, no more could my father, nor his father, nor none of the Ignorance this hundred year, I assure ye.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Your name proclaims no less, sir, and it has been a most learned generation.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Though I cannot write, I have set my mark. Ecce signum! Read it, I beseech ye.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: The mark of Simon Ignorance, the Bailey of Dunstable, being a sheep-hook with a tarbox at end on’t.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Very right. It was my mark ever since I was an innocent and therefore, as I say, I have begun and will assist ye, for here be rich whoresons i’ the town, I can tell ye, that will give ye the slip and ye look not to it.

speech.speaker: FLEM.
speech.line: We therefore presently will divide ourselves. You two shall stay here whilst we, Master Ignorance, with some of your brethren, the men of Dunstable, walk through the town noting the carriage of the people. They say there are strange songs and libels cast about the market place against my lord Tresilian and the rest of the King’s young Councilors. If such there be, we’ll have some aid and attach them speedily.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Ye shall do well, sir, and for your better aiding, if you can but find out my brother, Master Ignoramus, he will be most pestiferous unto ye, I assure ye.

speech.speaker: CROS.
speech.line: I’m afraid he will not be found, sir, but we’ll inquire. Come, fellow Fleming; and Nimble, look to the whisperers, I charge ye.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I warrant ye.
Come, Master Bailey, let your billmen retire till we call them, and you and I will here shadow ourselves and write down their speeches.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Nay, you shall write and I will mark, sir.

stagedir.dir: Enter a Farmer, a Butcher, and Cowtail, a grazier, very hastily.

speech.line: And see, see, here comes some already, all rich chubbs, by the Mass. I know them all, sir.

speech.speaker: FARM.
speech.line: Tarry, tarry, good neighbors, take a knave with ye! What a murrain! Is there a bear broke loose i’the town, that ye make such haste from the market?

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: A bear? No, nor a lion baited neither. I tell ye, neighbor, I am more afraid of the bee than the bear. There’s wax to be us’d today, and I have no seal about me. I may tell you in secret, here’s a dangerous world towards. Neighbor, you’re a farmer, and I hope here is none but God and good company. We live in such a state, I am e’en almost weary of all, I assure ye. Here’s my other neighbor, the butcher, that dwells at Hockley, has heard his landlord tell strange tidings. We shall be all hoisted and we tarry here, I can tell ye.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: They begin to murmur. I’ll put them down all for whisperers. Master Bailey, what’s he that talks so?

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: His name is Cowtail, a rich grazier, and dwells here hard by at Leighton Buzzard.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Cowtail, a grazier, dwelling at Leighton Buzzard, Master Bailey?

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Right, sir. Listen again, sir.

speech.speaker: FARM.
speech.line: Ah, sirrah? And what said the good knight, your landlord, neighbor?

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Marry, he said but I’ll not stand to anything, I tell ye that aforehand. He said that King Richard’s new Councilors (God amend them) had crept into honester men’s places than themselves were and that the King’s uncles and the old lords were all banish’d the court, and he said flatly we should never have a merry world as long as it was so.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Butcher, you and your landlord will be both hang’d for it.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: And then he said that there’s one Tresilian, a lawyer, that has crept in amongst them and is now a lord, forsooth, and he has sent down into every country of England a sort of black chapters.

speech.speaker: FARM.
speech.line: Black chapters? A’ God’s name, neighbor, out of what black book were they taken?

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: Come, come, they are Blank Charters, neighbors. I heard of them afore, and therefore I made such haste away. They’re sent down to the High Shrieve, with special charge that every man that is of any credit or worship in the country must set their hands and seal to them, for what intent I know not. I say no more, I smell something.

speech.speaker: FARM.
speech.line: Well, well, my masters, let’s be wise: we are not all one man’s sons. They say there are whispering knaves abroad. Let’s hie us home, for I assure ye, ’twas told me where I broke my fast this afternoon that there were above three-score gentlemen in our shire that had set their hands and seals to those Blank Charters already.

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: Now God amend them for it, they have given an ill example we shall be forc’d to follow.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: I would my wife and children were at Jerusalem with all the wealth! I’d make shift for one, I warrant them. Come, neighbors, let’s be gone.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Step forward with your bills, Master Bailey! Not so fast, sirs! I charge ye in the King’s name to stand till we have done with ye.

speech.speaker: ALL. TRADES.
speech.line: Saint Benedicite, what must we do now, trow?

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Be not so pestiferous, my good friends and neighbors. You are men of wealth and credit in the country and therefore, as I myself and others have begun, I charge ye in his Highness’ name presently to set your hands and seals to these Blank Charters.

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: Jesu, receive my soul, I’m departed!

speech.speaker: FARM.
speech.line: I’m e’en stroke to at heart too.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Alas, sir, we are poor men, what should our hands do?

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: There is no harm, I warrant ye. What need you fear, when ye see Bailey Ignorance has seal’d before ye?

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: I pray ye, let us see them, sir.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Here, ye bacon-fed pudding-eaters, are ye afraid of a sheepskin?

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: Mass, ’tis somewhat darkly written.

speech.speaker: FARM.
speech.line: Ay, ay, ’twas done i’the night, sure.

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: Mass, neighbors, here’s nothing that I see.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: And can it be any harm, think ye, to set your hands to nothing? These Blank Charters are but little pieces of parchment. Let’s set our marks to them, and be rid of a knave’s company.

speech.speaker: FARM.
speech.line: As good at first as last, we can be but undone.

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: Ay, and our own hands undoes us, that’s the worst on’t. Lend’s your pen, sir.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: We must all venture, neighbors, there’s no remedy.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: They grumble as they do it, I must put them down for whisperers and grumblers. Come, have you done yet?

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: Ay, sir.
Would you and they were sodden for my swine!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Here’s wax, then. I’ll seal them for ye, and you shall severally take them off and then deliver them as your deeds.
Come, you boar’s grease, take off this seal here. So, this is your deed?

speech.speaker: FARM.
speech.line: Faith, sir, in some respect it is and it is not.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: And this is yours?

speech.speaker: COW.
speech.line: Ay, sir, against my will, I swear.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Ox-jaw, take off this seal! You’ll deliver your deed with a good conscience?

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: There ’tis, sir, against my conscience, God’s my witness. I hope ye have done with us now, sir.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: No, ye caterpillars, we have worse matters against ye yet. Sirrah, you know what your landlord told ye concerning my lord Tresilian and King Richard’s new favorites; and, more than that, you know your own speeches. And therefore, Master Bailey, let some of your billmen away with them to the High Shrieve’s presently, either to put in bail or be sent up to the court for privy whisperers.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Their offenses are most pestiferous. Away with them!

speech.speaker: ALL. TRADES.
speech.line: Now out, alas, we shall all to hanging, sure!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Hanging? Nay, that’s the least on’t, ye shall tell me that a twelve-month hence else!

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Officers with the three men.

speech.line: Stand close, Master Bailey, we shall catch more of these traitors presently.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: You shall find me most pestiferous to assist ye; and so I pray ye, commend my service to your good lord and master. Come, sir, stand close; I see here.

stagedir.dir: Enter a Schoolmaster and his Servant.

speech.speaker: SCH. SERV.
speech.line: Nay, sweet Master Schoolmaster, let’s hear’t again, I beseech ye.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Patientia, you’re a servingman, I’m a scholar. I have shown art and learning in these verses, I assure ye, and yet if they were well search’dthey’re little better than libels. But the carriage of a thing is all, sir: I have cover’d them rarely.

speech.speaker: SCH. SERV.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, the country’s so full of intelligencers that two men can scarce walk together but they’re attach’d for whisperers.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: This paper shall wipe their noses, and they shall not say boo to a goose for’t; for I’ll have these verses sung to their faces by one of my schoolboys, wherein I’ll tickle them all, i’ faith. Shalt hear else, but first let’s look there be no pitchers with ears, nor needles with eyes about us.

speech.speaker: SCH. SERV.
speech.line: Come, come, all’s safe, I warrant ye.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Mark, then. Here I come over them for their Blank Charters; shalt hear else.
Will ye buy any parchment knives?
We sell for little gain: Whoe’er are weary of their lives
They’ll rid them of their pain.
Blank Charters they are call’d
A vengeance on the villain!
I would he were both flay’d and bald: God bless my lord Tresilian!
Is’t not rare?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Oh, rascals! They’re damn’d three hundred fathom deep already!

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Nay, look ye, sir, there can be no exceptions taken, for this last line helps all, wherein with a kind of equivocation I say, ‘God bless my lord Tresilian.’ Do ye mark, sir? Now here, in the next verse, I run o’er all these flatterers i’ the court by name. Ye shall see else:
A poison may be Green,
But Bushy can be no faggot: God mend the King and bless the Queen,
And ’tis no matter for Bagot.
For Scroop, he does no good;
But if you’ll know the villain,
His name is now to be understood:
God bless my lord Tresilian!
How like ye this, sir?

speech.speaker: SCH. SERV.
speech.line: Most excellent, i’faith, sir.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Oh, traitors! Master Bailey, do your authority!

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Two most pestiferous traitors! Lay hold of them, I charge ye!

speech.speaker: SCH. SERV.
speech.line: What mean ye, sir?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Nay, talk not, for if ye had a hundred lives they were all hang’d. Ye have spoken treason in the ninth degree.

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: Treason? Patientia, good sir, we spoke not a word!

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Be not so pestiferous, mine ears have heard your examinations, wherein you utter’d most shameful treason, for ye said, ‘God bless my lord Tresilian.’

speech.speaker: SCHOOL.
speech.line: I hope there’s no treason in that, sir.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: That shall be tried! Come, Master Bailey: their hands shall be bound under a horse’s belly and sent up to him presently. They’ll both be hang’d, I warrant them.

speech.speaker: SCH. SERV.
speech.line: Well, sir, if we be, we’ll speak more ere we be hang’d, in spite of ye.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Ay, ay, when you’re hang’d speak what you will, we care not. Away with them!

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Schoolmaster and his Servant with Officer.

speech.line: Ye see, Master Bailey, what knaves are abroad now you are here. ’Tis time to look about, ye see.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: I see there are knaves abroad indeed, sir. I speak for mine own part, I will do my best to reform the pestiferousness of the times. And as for example I have set my mark to the charters, so will I set mine eyes to observe these dangerous cases.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Close again, Master Bailey, here comes another whisperer, I see by some—Oh, villain, he whistles treason! I’ll lay hold of him myself.

speech.speaker: WHIST.
speech.line: Out, alas! What do ye mean, sir?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: A rank traitor, Master Bailey! Lay hold on him, for he has most erroneously and rebelliously whistled treason!

speech.speaker: WHIST.
speech.line: Whistl’d treason? Alas, sir, how can that be?

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Very easily, sir! There’s a piece of treason that flies up and down the country in the likeness of a ballad, and this being the very tune of it, thou hast whistl’d treason.

speech.speaker: WHIST.
speech.line: Alas, sir, ye know I spake not a word!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: That’s all one. If any man whistles treason,’tis as ill as speaking it. Mark me, Master Bailey: the bird whistles that cannot speak, and yet there be birds in a manner that can speak too. Your raven will call ye black, your crow will call ye knave, Master Bailey, ergo he that can whistle can speak, and therefore this fellow hath both spoke and whistl’d treason. How say you, Bailey Ignorance?

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Ye have argued well, sir, but ye shall hear me sift him nearer, for I do not think but there are greater heads in this matter. And therefore, my good fellow, be not pestiferous, but say and tell the truth, who did set you a-work? Or who was the cause of your whistling? Or did any man say to you, ‘Go whistle’?

speech.speaker: WHIST.
speech.line: Not any man, woman or child, truly, sir.

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: No? How durst you whistle, then? Or what cause had ye to do so?

speech.speaker: WHIST.
speech.line: The truth is, sir, I had lost two calves out of my pasture, and being in search for them, from the top of the hill I might spy you two i’ the bottom here, and took ye for my calves, sir; and that made me come whistling down for joy, in hope I had found them.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: More treason yet, he take a courtier and a Bailey for two calves! To limbo with him, he shall be quarter’d and then hang’d!

speech.speaker: WHIST.
speech.line: Good Master Bailey, be pitiful!

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: Why, law ye, sir, he makes a pitiful fellow of a Bailey tooâ€”away with him! Yet stay awhile, here comes your fellows, sir.

speech.speaker: CROS.
speech.line: Now, Master Bailey, are your Blanks sealed yet?

speech.speaker: BAIL.
speech.line: They are, sir. And we have done this day most strange and pestiferous service, I assure ye, sir.

speech.speaker: FLEM.
speech.line: Your care shall be rewarded. Come, fellow Nimble, we must to court about other employments. There are already thirteen thousand Blanks signed and return’d to the shrieves, and seven hundred sent up to the court for whisperers, out of all which my lord will fetch a round sum, I doubt it not. Come, let’s away.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Ay, ay, we’ll follow. Come, ye sheepbiter! Here’s a traitor of all traitors that not only speaks, but has whistled treason. Come, come, sir, I’ll spoil your whistle, I warrant ye!

stagedir.dir: Enter Tresilian with writings, and a Servant with bags of money.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Sirrah, are the bags seal’d?

speech.speaker: SERV. TRES.
speech.line: Yes, my lord.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Then take my keys and lock the money in my study safe. Bar and make sure, I charge ye. So, begone.

speech.speaker: SERV. TRES.
speech.line: I will, my lord.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: So, seven thousand pounds
From Bedford, Buckingham and Oxford shires,
These Blanks already have return’d the king.
So then there’s four for me and three for him;
Our pains in this must needs be satisfied.
Good husbands will make hay while the sun shines,
And so must we, for thus conclude these times:
So men be rich enough, they’re good enough.
Let fools make conscience how they get their coin,
I’ll please the King and keep me in his grace,
For princes’ favors purchase land apace.
These Blanks that I have scatter’d in the realm
Shall double his revenues to the crown.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: Now, Lord Tresilian, is this coin come yet?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: King Richard wants money, you’re too slack, Tresilian.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Some shires have sent, and more, my lords, will follow.
These sealed Blanks I now have turn’d to bonds,
And these shall down to Norfolk presently.
The chuffs with much ado have sign’d and seal’d,
And here’s a secret note my men have sent
Of all their yearly ’states amounts unto,
And by this note I justly tax their bonds.
Here’s a fat whoreson in his russet slops,
And yet may spend three hundred pounds by th’ year,
The third of which the hogsface owes the King.
Here’s his bond for’t, with his hand and seal,
And so by this I’ll sort each several sum:
The thirds of all shall to King Richard come.
How like you this, my lords?

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: Most rare, Tresilian. Hang ’em, codsheads. Shall they spend money and King Richard lack it?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Are not their lives and lands and livings his? Then rack them thoroughly!

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Oh, my lords, I have set a trick afoot for ye; an’ ye follow it hard and get the king to sign it, you’ll be all kings by it.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: The farming out the kingdom? Tush, Tresilian, ’tis half granted already, and had been fully concluded had not the messenger returned so unluckily from the Duke of Gloucester, which a little mov’d the King at his uncle’s stubbornness. But to make all whole, we have left that smooth-fac’d, flattering Green to follow him close, and he’ll never leave till he has done it, I warrant ye.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: There’s no question on’t; King Richard will betake himself to a yearly stipend, and we four by lease must rent the kingdom.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Rent it, ay, and rack it too, ere we forfeit our leases, and we had them once.
How now, Bagot, what news?

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: All rich and rare: the realm must be divided presently, and we four must farm it. The leases are a-making and for seven thousand pounds a month the kingdom is our own, boys!

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, let’s differ for no price! And it were seventy thousand pounds a month we’ll make somebody pay for’t.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: Where is his Highness?

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: He will be here presently to seal the writings. He’s a little angry that the Duke comes not, but that will vanish quickly. On with your soothest faces, ye wenching rascals. Humor him finely, and you’re all made by it.

stagedir.dir: Sound a flourish. Enter King Richard, Green, and others.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: See, see, he comes, and that flattering hound Green close at his elbow.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: Come, come, we must all flatter if we mean to live by it.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Our uncle will not come, then?

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: That was his answer, flat and resolute.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Was ever subject so audacious?

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: And can your Grace, my lord, digest these wrongs?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Yes, as a mother that beholds her child
Dismember’d by a bloody tyrant’s sword!
I tell thee, Bagot, in my heart remains
Such deep impressions of his churlish taunts,
As nothing can remove the gall thereof
Till with his blood mine eyes be satisfied.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, raise powers, my lord, and fetch him thence perforce!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I dare not, Green, for whilst he keeps i’ the country
There is no meddling. He’s so well belov’d
As all the realm will rise in arms with him.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, my lord, and you’d fain have him, I have a trick shall fetch him from his house at Plashy in spite of all his favorites.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Let’s ha’t, Tresilian, thy wit must help or all’s dash’d else.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Then thus, my lord: whilst the Duke securely revels i’ the country, we'll have some trusty friends disguise themselves like maskers and this night ride down to Plashy, and in the name of some near-adjoining friends offer their sports to make him merry, which he no doubt will thankfully accept. Then in the masque we’ll have it so devis’d, the dance being done and the room voided, then upon some occasion single the Duke alone, thrust him in a masquing suit, clap a vizard on his face, and so convey him out of the house at pleasure.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: How if he cry and call for help?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: What serves your drums but to drown his cries? And being in a masque, ’twill never be suspected.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Good, i’ faith. And to help it, my lord, Lapoole, the Governor of Calais, is new come over, who, with a troop of soldiers closely ambush’d in the woods near the house, shall shroud themselves till the masque be ended. Then, the Duke being attach’d, he shall be there ready to receive him, hurry him away to the Thames’ side where a ship shall be laid ready for his coming, so clap him under hatches, hoist sails, and secretly convey him out o’ the realm to Calais And so by this means ye shall prevent all mischief, for neither of your uncles nor any of the kingdom shall know what’s become of him.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I like it well, sweet Green; and by my crown
We’ll be in the masque ourself, and so shall you.
Get horses ready, this night we’ll ride to Plashy;
But see ye carry it close and secretly,
For whilst this plot’s a-working for the Duke,
I’ll set a trap for York and Lancaster.
Go, Tresilian, let proclamations straight be sent
Wherein thou shalt accuse the dukes of treason,
And then attach, condemn, and close imprison them.
Lest the commons should rebel against us,
We’ll send unto the King of France for aid,
And in requital we’ll surrender up
Our forts of Guisnes and Calais to the French.
Let crown and kingdom waste, yea life and all,
Before King Richard see his true friends fall!
Give order our disguises be made ready,
And let Lapoole provide the ship and soldiers.
We will not sleep, by heaven, till we have seiz’d him!

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, urge our suit again, he will forget it else.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: These traitors once surpris’d, then all is sure:
Our kingdom quiet and your states secure.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Most true, sweet king. And then your Grace, as you promis’d, farming out the kingdom to us four, shall not need to trouble yourself with any business. This old turkey-cock, Tresilian, shall look to the law, and we’ll govern the land most rarely.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: So, sir. The love of thee and these, my dearest Green,
Hath won King Richard to consent to that
For which all foreign kings will point at us.
And of the meanest subject of our land
We shall be censur’d strongly, when they tell
How our great father toil’d his royal person
Spending his blood to purchase towns in France,
And we, his son, to ease our wanton youth,
Become a landlord to this warlike realm,
Rent out our kingdom like a pelting farm,
That erst was held, as far as Babylon,
The maiden conqueress to all the world.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, what need you care what the world talks? You still retain the name of king, and if any disturb ye, we four comes presently from the four parts of the kingdom with four puissant armies to assist you.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: You four must be all then, for I think nobody else will follow you, unless it be to hanging!

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Why, Richard, King Richard, will ye be as good as your word, and seal the writings? ’Sfoot, an’ thou dost not, and I do not join with thine uncles and turn traitor, would I might be turn’d to a toadstool!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Very well, sir. They did well to choose you for their orator, that has King Richard’s love and heart in keeping. Your suit is granted, sir; let’s see the writings.

speech.speaker: ALL. FAV.
speech.line: They’re here, my lord!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: View them, Tresilian, then we’ll sign and seal them. Look to your bargain, Green, and be no loser, for if ye forfeit or run behind-hand with me, I swear I’ll both imprison and punish ye soundly.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Forfeit, sweet king? ’Sblood, I’ll sell their houses ere I’ll forfeit my lease, I warrant thee.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: If they be stubborn, do, and spare not. Rack them soundly and we’ll maintain it. Remember ye not the proviso enacted in our last parliament, that no statute, were it ne’er so profitable for the commonwealth, should stand in any force ’gainst our proceedings?

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: ’Tis true, my lord: then what should hinder ye to accomplish anything that may best please your kingly spirit to determine?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: True, Green, and we will do it, in spite of them. Is’t just, Tresilian?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Most just, my liege. These gentlemen here, Sir Henry Green, Sir Edward Bagot, Sir William Bushy, and Sir Thomas Scroop, all jointly here stand bound to pay your Majesty, or your deputy, wherever you remain, seven thousand pounds a month for this your kingdom; for which your Grace, by these writings, surrenders to their hands all your crown lands, lordships, manors, rents, taxes, subsidies, fifteens, imposts, foreign customs, staples for wool, tin, lead, and cloth; all forfeitures of goods or lands confiscate, and all other duties that is, shall, or may appertain to the king or crown’s revenues; and for non-payment of the sum or sums aforesaid, your Majesty to seize the lands and goods of the said gentlemen above named, and their bodies to be imprisoned at your Grace’s pleasure.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How like you that, Green? Believe me, if you fail, I’ll not favor ye a day.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: I’ll ask no favor at your hands, sir. Ye shall have your money at your day, and then do your worst, sir!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: ’Tis very good. Set to your hands and seals. Tresilian, we make you our deputy to receive this money. Look strictly to them, I charge ye.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: If the money come not to my hands at the time appointed, I’ll make them smoke for’t.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Ay, ay, you’re an upright justice, sir, we fear ye not. Here, my lord, they’re ready, sign’d and seal’d.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Deliver them to his Majesty all together, as your special deeds.

speech.speaker: ALL. FAV.
speech.line: We do, with humble thanks unto his Majesty,
That makes us tenants to so rich a lordship.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Keep them, Tresilian; now will we sign and seal to you. Never had English subjects such a landlord.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Nor never had English king such subjects as we four, that are able to farm a whole kingdom and pay him rent for’t.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Look that ye do. We shall expect performance speedily. There’s your indenture, sign’d and seal’d, which as our kingly deed we here deliver.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Thou never did’st a better deed in thy life, sweet bully! Thou may’st now live at ease: we’ll toil for thee, and send thy money in tumbling.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We shall see your care, sir. Reach me the map, that we may allot their portions, and part the realm amongst them equally. You four shall here by us divide yourselves into the nine-and-thirty shires and counties of my kingdom, parted thus. Come stand by me and mark those shires assign’d ye. Bagot, thy lot betwixt the Thames and sea thus lies: Kent, Surrey, Sussex, Hampshire, Berkshire, Wiltshire, Dorsetshire, Somersetshire, Devonshire, Cornwall. Those parts are thine as amply, Bagot, as the crown is mine.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: All thanks, love, duty to my princely sovereign.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Bushy from thee shall stretch his government over these lands that lie in Wales, together with our counties of Gloucester, Worcester, Hereford, Shropshire, Staffordshire and Cheshire.
There’s thy lot.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Thanks to my king that thus hath honor’d me.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Sir Thomas Scroop, from Trent to Tweed thy lot is parted thus: all Yorkshire, Derbyshire, Lancashire, Cumberland, Westmoreland, and Northumberland. Receive thy lot, thy state and government.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: With faith and duty to your Highness’ throne.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Now, my Green, what have I left for thee?

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, and you’ll give me nothing, then good night, landlord! Since ye have serv’d me last, and I be not the last shall pay your rent, ne’er trust me!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I kept thee last, to make thy part the greatest.
See here, sweet Green,
These shires are thine, even from the Thames to Trent.
Thou here shalt lie, i’ the middle of my land.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: That’s best i’ the winter. Is there any pretty wenches in my government?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Guess that by this: thou hast London, Middlesex, Essex, Suffolk, Norfolk, Cambridgeshire, Hertfordshire, Bedfordshire, Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Northamptonshire, Rutlandshire, Leicestershire, Warwickshire, Huntingdonshire, and Lincolnshire. There’s your portion, sir.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: ’Slid, I will rule like a king amongst them,
And thou shalt reign like an emperor over us.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thus have I parted my whole realm amongst ye;
Be careful of your charge and government.
And now to attach our stubborn uncles.
Let warrants be sent down, Tresilian,
For Gaunt and York, Surrey and Arundel,
Whilst we this night at Plashy suddenly
Surprise plain Woodstock. Being parted thus,
We shall with greater ease arrest and take them.
Your places are not sure while they have breath,
Therefore pursue them hard: those traitors gone,
The staves are broke the people lean upon,
And you may guide and rule them at your pleasures.
Away to Plashy, let our masque be ready.
Beware, plain Thomas, for King Richard comes
Resolv’d with blood to wash all former wrongs!

stagedir.dir: Flourish of trumpets, and exeunt omnes.
Enter Woodstock and his Duchess with a Gentleman Messenger, Cheney, and others.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: The Queen so sick! Come, come, make haste good wife,
Thou’lt be belated sure, ’tis night already!
On with thy cloak and mask! To horse, to horse!

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Good troth, my lord, I have no mind to ride.
I have been dull and heavy all this day,
My sleeps were troubled with sad dreams last night,
And I am full of fear and heaviness.
Pray, let me ride tomorrow.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: What, and the Queen so sick? Away, for shame!
Stay for a dream? Thou’st dreamt, I’m sure, ere this!

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Never so fearful were my dreams till now.
Had they concern’d myself, my fears were past;
But you were made the object of mine eye,
And I beheld you murder’d cruelly.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ha, murder’d?
Alack, good lady, did’st thou dream of me?
Take comfort, then, all dreams are contrary.

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: Pray God it prove so, for my soul is fearful,
The vision did appear so lively to me.
Methought as you were ranging through the woods
An angry lion with a herd of wolves
Had in an instant round encompass’d you;
When to your rescue, ’gainst the course of kind,
A flock of silly sheep made head against them,
Bleating for help, ’gainst whom the forest king
Rous’d up his strength, and slew both you and them.
This fear affrights me.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Afore my God, thou’rt foolish, I’ll tell thee all thy dream.
Thou know’st last night we had some private talk
About the Blanks the country’s tax’d withal,
Where I compar’d the state as now it stands,
Meaning King Richard and his harmful flatterers,
Unto a savage herd of ravening wolves,
The Commons to a flock of silly sheep
Who, whilst their slothful shepherd careless stood,
Those forest thieves broke in, and suck’d their blood.
And this thy apprehension took so deep,
The form was portray’d lively in thy sleep.
Come, come, ’tis nothing. What, are her horses ready?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: They are, my lord.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Where is the gentleman that brought this message?
Where lies the Queen, sir?

speech.speaker: GENT. MESS.
speech.line: At Sheen, my lord, most sick, and so much alter’d
As those about her fears her sudden death.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Forfend it, heaven! Away, make haste, I charge ye.
What, weeping now? Afore my God, thou’rt fond!
Come, come, I know thou art no augurer of ill.
Dry up thy tears. This kiss, and part. Farewell!

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: That farewell from your lips to me sounds ill.
Where’er I go, my fears will follow still.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: See her to horseback, Cheney.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Duchess and the rest. Manet Woodstock.

speech.line: ’Fore my God, ’tis late,
And but th’ important business craves such haste,
She had not gone from Plashy House tonight.
But woe is me, the good Queen Anne is sick
And, by my soul, my heart is sad to hear it.
So good a lady, and so virtuous,
This realm for many ages could not boast of.
Her charity hath stay’d the commons’ rage
That would ere this have shaken Richard’s chair
Or set all England on a burning fire.
And ’fore my God I fear when she is gone
This woeful land will all to ruin run.
How now, Cheney, what, is thy lady gone yet?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: She is, my lord, with much unwillingness,
And ’tis so dark I cannot blame her Grace.
The lights of heaven are shut in pitchy clouds
And flakes of fire run tilting through the sky
Like dim ostents to some great tragedy.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: God bless good Anne a’ Beame; I fear her death
Will be the tragic scene the sky foreshows us.
When kingdoms change, the very heavens are troubled.
Pray God King Richard’s wild behavior
Force not the powers of heaven to frown upon us.
My prayers are still for him. What think’st thou, Cheney,
May not plain Thomas live a time to see
This state attain her former royalty?
’Fore God, I doubt it not! My heart is merry,
And I am suddenly inspir’d for mirth.
Ha, what sport shall we have tonight, Cheney?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: I’m glad to see your Grace addicted so,
For I have news of sudden mirth to tell ye
Which, till I heard ye speak, I durst not utter:
We shall have a masque tonight, my lord.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ha, a masque say’st thou? What are they, Cheney?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: It seems, my lord, some country gentlemen,
To show their dear affection to your Grace,
Proffer their sports this night to make you merry.
Their drums have call’d for entrance twice already.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Are they so near? I prithee, let them enter.
Tell them we do embrace their loves most kindly.
Give order through the house that all observe them.
We must accept their loves, although the times
Are no way suited now for masques and revels.
What ho, within there!

speech.speaker: SERV. WOOD.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Prepare a banquet: call for lights and music.
They come in love, and we’ll accept it so.
Some sports does well, we’re all too full of woe.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: They’re come, my lord.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: They all are welcome, Cheney. Set me a chair,
We will behold their sports in spite of care.

stagedir.dir: A flourish of cornets, then a great shout and winding of horns. Enter Cynthia.

speech.speaker: CYN.
speech.line: From the clear orb of our ethereal sphere
Bright Cynthia comes to hunt and revel here.
The groves of Calydon and Arden Woods
Of untam’d monsters, wild and savage herds,
We and our knights have freed, and hither come
To hunt these forests, where we hear there lies
A cruel tusked boar, whose terror flies
Through this large kingdom, and with fear and dread
Strikes her amazed greatness pale and dead.
And, having view’d from far these towers of stone,
We heard the people midst their joy and moan
Extol to heaven a faithful prince and peer
That keeps a court of love and pity here.
Reverend and mild his looks: if such there be,
This state directs, great prince, that you are he;
And ere our knights to this great hunting go,
Before your Grace they would some pastime show
In sprightly dancing. Thus they bade me say,
And wait an answer to return or stay.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Nay, for heaven’s pity, let them come, I prithee.
Pretty device, i’faith! Stand by, make room there!
Stir, stir, good fellows, each man to his task,
We shall have a clear night, the moon directs the masque.

stagedir.dir: Music. Enter King Richard, Green, Bushy and Bagot, like Diana’s knights in green, with horns about their necks and boar-spears in their hands.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ha, country sports, say ye? ’Fore God, ’tis courtly.
A general welcome, courteous gentlemen,
And when I see your faces, I’ll give each man more particular.
If your entertainment fail your merit,
I must ask pardon: my lady is from home
And most of my attendants waiting on her.
But we’ll do what we can to bid you welcome.
Afore my God, it joys my heart to see
Amidst these days of woe and misery
Ye find a time for harmless mirth and sport.
But ’tis your loves, and we’ll be thankful for’t.
Ah, sirrah, ye come like knights to hunt the boar indeed;
And heaven he knows we had need of helping hands,
So many wild boars roots and spoils our lands
That England almost is destroy’d by them.
I care not if King Richard hear me speak it:
I wish his Grace all good, high heaven can tell,
But there’s a fault in some, alack the day:
His youth is led by flatterers much astray.
But he’s our king and God’s great deputy,
And if ye hunt to have me second ye
In any rash attempt against his state,
Afore my God, I’ll ne’er consent unto it.
I ever yet was just and true to him,
And so will still remain. What’s now amiss
Our sins have caus’d, and we must bide heaven’s will.
I speak my heart: I am Plain Thomas still.
Come, come, a hall, and music there! Your dance being done,
A banquet stands prepar’d to bid you welcome.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: How now, Cheney, is this banquet ready?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: There is no time, I fear, for banqueting,
My lord. I wish your Grace be provident,
I fear your person is betray’d. My lord,
The house is round beset with armed soldiers.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ha, soldiers?
Afore my God, the commons all are up, then.
They will rebel against the King, I fear me,
And flock to me to back their bold attempts.
Go arm the household, Cheney!
Hear me, gentlemen:
’Fore God, I do not like this whispering.
If your intents be honest, show your faces.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Guard fast the doors and seize him presently!
This is the cave that keeps the tusked boar
That roots up England’s vineyards uncontroll’d.
Bagot, arrest him! If for help he cry,
Drown all his words with drums confusedly.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Am I betray’d?

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Ye cannot ’scape, my lord, the toils are pitch’d
And all your household fast in hold ere this.
Thomas of Woodstock, Duke of Gloucester,
Earl of Cambridge and of Buckingham,
I here arrest thee in King Richard’s name
Of treason to the crown, his state and realm.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: I’ll put in bail, and answer to the law.
Speak, is King Richard here?

speech.speaker: ALL MASK.
speech.line: No, no, my lord.
Away with him!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Villains, touch me not!
I am descended of the royal blood,
King Richard’s uncle, his grandsire’s son,
His princely father’s brother!
Becomes it princes to be led like slaves?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Put on a vizard! Stop his cries!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Ha, who bids them so? I know that voice full well.
Afore my God, false men, King Richard’s here!
Turn thee, thou headstrong youth, and speak again!
By thy dead father’s soul, I charge thee, hear me,
So heaven may help me at my greatest need,
As I have wish’d thy good and England’s safety.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: You’re still deceiv’d, my lord, the King’s not here.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: On with his masquing suit, and bear him hence!
We’ll lead ye fairly to King Richard’s presence.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Nay, from his presence to my death you’ll lead me;
And I am pleas’d I shall not live to see
My country’s ruin, and his misery.
Thou hear’st me well, proud king, and well may’st boast
That thou betray’d’st me here so suddenly,
For had I known thy secret treachery,
Nor thou, nor these thy flattering minions,
With all your strengths had wrong’d plain Woodstock thus.
But use your wills. Your uncles, Gaunt and York,
Will give you thanks for this; and the poor commons,
When they shall hear of these your unjust proceedings

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Stop’s mouth, I say, we’ll hear no more!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Good heaven, forgive me, pray ye forbear awhile,
I’ll speak but one word more, indeed I will.
Some man commend me to my virtuous wife,
Tell her her dreams have ta’en effect indeed:
By wolves and lions now must Woodstock bleed.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Deliver him to Lapoolethe ship lies ready.
Convey him o’er to Calais speedily,
There use him as we gave directions.
Sound up your drums, our hunting sports are done,
And when you’re past the house, cast by your habits
And mount your horses with all swiftest haste.
The boar is taken, and our fears are past!

speech.speaker: CROS.
speech.line: Come, sirs, attend; my lord is coming forth.
The High Shrieves of Kent and Northumberland
With twenty gentlemen are all arrested
For privy whisperers against the state,
In which I know my lord will find some trick
To seize their goods, and then there’s work for us.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Nay, there will be work for the hangman first; then we rifle the goods and my lord seizes the lands. If these seven hundred whisperers that are taken come off lustily, he’ll have the devil and all shortly.

stagedir.dir: Enter Tresilian with the Sheriffs of Kent and Northumberland guarded by Officers.

speech.speaker: FLEM.
speech.line: See, see, they’re coming.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Call for a marshal there! Commit the traitors!

speech.speaker: SHER. KENT.
speech.line: We do beseech your Honor, hear us speak.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Sir, we’ll not hear ye, the proof’s too plain against ye.
Becomes it you, sir, being Shrieve of Kent,
To stay the Blanks King Richard sent abroad,
Revile our messengers, refuse the Charters,
And spurn like traitors ’gainst the King’s decrees?

speech.speaker: SHER. KENT.
speech.line: My lord, I plead our ancient liberties
Recorded and enroll’d in the king’s Crown Office,
Wherein the men of Kent are clear discharg’d
Of fines, fifteens, or any other taxes,
Forever given them by the Conqueror.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: You’re still deceiv’d. Those Charters were not sent
To abrogate your ancient privilege,
But for his Highness’ use they were devis’d
To gather and collect amongst his subjects
Such sums of money as they well might spare,
And he in their defense must hourly spend.
Is not the subjects’ wealth at the King’s will?
What, is he lord of lives and not of lands?
Is not his high displeasure present death?
And dare ye stir his indignation so?

speech.speaker: SHER. NORTH.
speech.line: We are free-born, my lord, yet do confess
Our lives and goods are at the King’s dispose,
But how, my lord, like to a gentle prince,
To take or borrow what we best may spare,
And not, like bond-slaves, force it from our hands.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Presumptuous traitors, that will we try on you.
Will you set limits to the King’s high pleasure?
Away to prison! Seize their goods and lands!

speech.speaker: SHER. KENT.
speech.line: Much good may it do ye, my lord, the care is ta’en;
As good die there as here abroad be slain.

speech.speaker: SHER. NORTH.
speech.line: Well, God forgive both you and us, my lord.
Your hard oppressions have undone the state
And made all England poor and desolate.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Why suffer ye their speech? To prison, hie!
There let them perish, rot, consume, and die!
Art thou there, Nimble?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I am here, my lord; and since your lordship is now employ’d to punish traitors, I am come to present myself unto you.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: What, for a traitor?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: No, my lord, but for a discoverer of the strangest traitor that was ever heard of, for by the plain arithmetic of my capacity, I have found out the very words a traitor spoke that has whistl’d treason.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: How is that, whistle treason?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Most certain, my lord, I have a trick for’t. If a carman do but whistle, I’ll find treason in it, I warrant ye.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Thou’rt a rare statesman, Nimble, thou’st a reaching head.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I’ll put treason into any man’s head, my lord, let him answer it as he can. And then, my lord, we have got a schoolmaster that teaches all the country to sing treason, and like a villain he says God bless your lordship!

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Thou’rt a most strange discoverer! Where are these traitors?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: All in prison, my lord. Master Ignorance, the Bailey of Dunstable, and I, have taken great pains about them. Besides, here’s a note of seven hundred whisperers, most o’ them sleepy knaves. We pull’d them out of Bedfordshire.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Let’s see the note. Seven hundred whispering traitors?
Monstrous villains! We must look to these:
Of all the sort, these are most dangerous
To stir rebellion ’gainst the King and us.
What are they, Crosby? Are the rebels wealthy?

speech.speaker: CROS.
speech.line: Fat chuffs, my lord, all landed men. Rich farmers, graziers and such fellows that, having been but a little pinch’d with imprisonment, begin already to offer their lands for liberty.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: We’ll not be nice to take their offers, Crosby,
Their lands are better than their lives to us,
And without lands they shall not ransom lives.
Go, sirs, to terrify the traitors more,
Ye shall have warrants straight to hang them all;
Then, if they proffer lands and put in bail
To make a just surrender speedily,
Let them have lives, and after, liberty.
But those that have nor lands nor goods to pay,
Let them be whipp’d, then hang’d. Make haste, away.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Well, then, I see my whistler must be whipp’d: he has but two calves to live on, and has lost them too. And for my schoolmaster, I’ll have him march about the market place with ten dozen of rods at his girdle the very day he goes a-feasting, and every one of his scholars shall have a jerk at him.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Away and leave us. Here comes Sir Edward Bagot.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Come, sirs.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Nimble, Crosby, and the others.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Right happily met, my lord Tresilian.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: You’re well return’d to court, Sir Edward,
To this sad house of Sheen, made comfortless
By the sharp sickness of the good Queen Anne.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: King Richard’s come, and gone to visit her.
Sad for her weak estate, he sits and weeps.
Her speech is gone. Only at sight of him
She heav’d her hands and clos’d her eyes again,
And whether alive or dead is yet uncertain.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Here comes Sir William Bushy. What tidings, sir?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: The King’s a widower, sir. Fair Anne a’ Beame
Hath breath’d her last farewell to all the realm.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Peace with her soul, she was a virtuous lady.
How takes King Richard this her sudden death?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Fares like a madman: rends his princely hair,
Beats his sad breast, falls groveling on the earth
All careless of his state, wishing to die
And even in death to keep her company.
But that which makes his soul more desperate,
Amidst this heat of passion, weeping comes
His aunt the Duchess, Woodstock’s hapless wife,
With tender love and comfort,
At sight of whom his griefs again redoubled,
Calling to mind the lady’s woeful state,
As yet all ignorant of her own mishap.
He takes her in his arms, weeps on her breast,
And would have there reveal’d her husband’s fall
Amidst his passions, had not Scroop and Green
By violence borne him to an inward room,
Where still he cries to get a messenger
To send to Calais to reprieve his uncle.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: I do not like those passions.
If he reveal the plot we all shall perish.
Where is the Duchess?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: With much ado we got her leave the presence
With an intent in haste to ride to Plashy.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: She’ll find sad comforts there. Would all were well.
A thousand dangers round enclose our state.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: And we’ll break through, my lord, in spite of fate.
Come, come, be merry, good Tresilian.

stagedir.dir: Enter King Richard, Green and Scroop.

speech.line: Here comes King Richard, all go comfort him.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: My dearest lord, forsake these sad laments.
No sorrows can suffice to make her live.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then let sad sorrow kill King Richard too,
For all my earthly joys with her must die
And I am kill’d with cares eternally,
For Anne a’ Beame is dead, forever gone!
She was too virtuous to remain with me,
And heaven hath given her higher dignity.
Oh, God, I fear even here begins our woe:
Her death’s but chorus to some tragic scene
That shortly will confound our state and realm.
Such sad events black mischiefs still attend,
And bloody acts, I fear, must crown the end.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Presage not so, sweet prince, your state is strong.
Your youthful hopes with expectation crown;
Let not one loss so many comforts drown.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Despair and madness seize me! Oh, my dear friends,
What loss can be compar’d to such a queen?
Down with this house of Sheen! Go, ruin all,
Pull down her buildings, let her turrets fall!
Forever lay it waste and desolate,
That English king may never here keep court,
But to all ages leave a sad report,
When men shall see these ruin’d walls of Sheen
And sighing say, here died King Richard’s queen.
For which we’ll have it wasted lime and stone
To keep a monument of Richard’s moan.
Oh, torturing grief!

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Oh, dear my liege, all tears for her are vain oblations,
Her quiet soul rests in celestial peace.
With joy of that, let all your sorrows cease.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Send post to Calais and bid Lapoole forbear
On pain of life to act our sad decree.
For heaven’s love, go, prevent the tragedy!
We have too much provok’d the powers divine,
And here repent thy wrongs, good uncle Woodstock,
The thought whereof confounds my memory.
If men might die when they would point the time,
The time is now King Richard would be gone;
For as a fearful thunderclap doth strike
The soundest body of the tallest oak,
Yet harmless leaves the outward bark untouch’d,
So is King Richard struck. Come, come, let’s go.
My wounds are inward. Inward burn my woe!

stagedir.dir: Woodstock sleeps. Enter Lapoole with a light, after him two Murderers.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Come, sirs, be resolute. The time serves well
To act the business you have ta’en in hand.
The Duke is gone to rest, the room is voided,
No ear can hear his cries. Be fearless, bold,
And win King Richard’s love, with heaps of gold.
Are all your instruments for death made ready?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: All fit to the purpose. See, my lord, here’s first a towel with which we do intend to strangle him; but if he strive and this should chance to fail, I’ll mall his old maz-zard with this hammer, knock him down like an ox, and after cut’s throat. How like ye this?

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: No, wound him not,
It must be done so fair and cunningly
As if he died a common natural death,
For so we must give out to all that ask.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: There is no way then but to smother him.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: I like that best; yet one thing let me tell ye:
Think not your work contriv’d so easily
As if you were to match some common man.
Believe me, sirs, his countenance is such,
So full of dread and lordly majesty,
Mix’d with such mild and gentle ’havior,
As will (except you be resolv’d at full)
Strike you with fear even with his princely looks.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Not and he look’d as grim as Hercules,
As stern and terrible as the devil himself!

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: ’Tis well resolv’d. Retire yourselves awhile:
Stay in the next withdrawing chamber there,
And when I spy the best advantage for ye, I’ll call ye forth.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Do but beckon with your finger, my lord, and like vultures we come flying and seize him presently.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Do so.
And yet, by all my fairest hopes, I swear
The boldness of these villains to this murder
Makes me abhor them and the deed forever.
Horror of conscience with the King’s command
Fights a fell combat in my fearful breast.
The King commands his uncle here must die,
And my sad conscience bids the contrary
And tells me that his innocent blood thus spilt
Heaven will revenge. Murder’s a heinous guilt,
A seven-times crying sin. Accursed man!
The further that I wade in this foul act
My troubled senses are the more distract,
Confounded and tormented past my reason.
But there’s no lingering: either he must die
Or great King Richard vows my tragedy.
Then ’twixt two evils ’tis good to choose the least:
Let danger fright faint fools, I’ll save mine own
And let him fall to black destruction.
He sleeps upon his bed. The time serves fitly,
I’ll call the murderers in. Sound music there,
To rock his senses in eternal slumbers.
Sleep, Woodstock, sleep. Thou never more shalt wake.
This town of Calais shall forever tell,
Within her castle walls plain Thomas fell.

stagedir.dir: Thunder and lightning. Enter the Ghost of the Black Prince.

speech.speaker: GHO. EDW.
speech.line: Night, horror and th’eternal shrieks of death
Intended to be done this dismal night
Hath shook fair England’s great cathedral,
And from my tomb elate at Canterbury
The ghost of Edward the Black Prince is come
To stay King Richard’s rage, my wanton son.
Thomas of Woodstock, wake! Thy brother calls thee.
Thou royal issue of King Edward’s loins,
Thou art beset with murder! Rise and fly,
If here thou stay, death comes and thou must die.
Still dost thou sleep? Oh, I am naught but air!
Had I the vigor of my former strength
When thou beheld’st me fight at CrÃ©cy Field,
Where, hand-to-hand, I took King John of France
And his bold sons my captive prisoners,
I’d shake these stiff supporters of thy bed
And drag thee from this dull security.
Oh, yet for pity, wake! Prevent thy doom!
Thy blood upon my son will surely come,
For which, dear brother Woodstock, haste and fly,
Prevent his ruin and thy tragedy, oh!

stagedir.dir: Thunder. Exit Ghost. Enter the Ghost of Edward the Third.

speech.speaker: GHO. KING EDW.
speech.line: Sleep’st thou so soundly and pale death so nigh?
Thomas of Woodstock, wake, my son, and fly!
Thy wrongs have rous’d thy royal father’s ghost
And from his quiet grave King Edward’s come
To guard thy innocent life, my princely son.
Behold me here: sometime fair England’s lord,
Seven warlike sons I left; yet, being gone,
Not one succeeded in my kingly throne.
Richard of Bordeaux, my accursed grandchild,
Cut off your titles to the kingly state
And now your lives and all would ruinate:
Murders his grandsire’s sons his father’s brothers!
Becomes a landlord to my kingly titles,
Rents out my crown’s revenues, racks my subjects
That spent their bloods with me in conquering France,
Beheld me ride in state through London streets,
And at my stirrup lowly footing by
Four captive kings to grace my victory.
Yet that nor this his riotous youth can stay,
Till death hath ta’en his uncles all away.
Thou fifth of Edward’s sons, get up and fly!
Haste thee to England, close and speedily!
Thy brothers York and Gaunt are up in arms;
Go join with them, prevent thy further harms.
The murderers are at hand. Awake, my son!
This hour foretells thy sad destruction.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Oh, good angels, guide me! Stay, thou blessed spirit,
Thou royal shadow of my kingly father,
Return again! I know thy reverend looks:
With thy dear sight once more recomfort me,
Put by the fears my trembling heart foretells
And here is made apparent to my sight
By dreams and visions of this dreadful night.
Upon my knees I beg it. Ha, protect me, heaven!
The doors are all made fast: ’twas but my fancy.
All’s whist and still, and nothing here appears
But the vast circuit of this empty room.
Thou blessed hand of mercy, guide my senses!
Afore my God, methought as here I slept,
I did behold in lively form and substance
My father Edward and my warlike brother
Both gliding by my bed, and cried to me
To leave this place, to save my life, and fly.
Lighten my fears, dear Lord! I here remain
A poor old man, thrust from my native country,
Kept and imprison’d in a foreign kingdom.
If I must die, bear record, righteous heaven,
How I have nightly wak’d for England’s good,
And yet to right her wrongs would spend my blood.
Send thy sad doom, King Richard, take my life,
I wish my death might ease my country’s grief.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: We are prevented. Back, retire again
He’s risen from his bed. What fate preserves him?
My lord, how fare you?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Thou can’st not kill me, villain!
God’s holy angel guards a just man’s life
And with his radiant beams as bright as fire
Will guard and keep his righteous innocence.
I am a prince, thou dar’st not murder me!

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Your Grace mistakes, my lord.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: What art thou? Speak!

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Lapoole, my lord, this city’s governor.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Lapoole, thou art King Richard’s flatterer.
Oh, you just gods, record their treachery,
Judge their foul wrongs that under show of friendship
Betray’d my simple, kind intendiments!
My heart misgave it was no time for revels
When you like maskers came disguis’d to Plashy
Join’d with that wanton king to trap my life
For that I know’s the end his malice aims at.
This castle, and my secret sending hither,
Imports no less. Therefore, I charge ye tell me,
Even by the virtue of nobility,
And partly, too, on that allegiance
Thou ow’st the offspring of King Edward’s house,
If aught thou know’st to prejudice my life,
Thou presently reveal, and make it known.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Nay, good my lord, forbear that fond suspicion.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: I tell thee, Poole, there is no less intended.
Why am I sent thus from my native country,
But here at Calais to be murdered?
And that, Lapoole, confounds my patience.
This town of Calais, where I spent my blood
To make it captive to the English king,
Before whose walls great Edward lay encamp’d
With his seven sons, almost for fourteen months;
Where the Black Prince, my brother, and myself,
The peers of England, and our royal father,
Fearless of wounds, ne’er left till it was won
And was’t to make a prison for his son?
Oh, righteous heavens, why do you suffer it?

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Disquiet not your thoughts, my gracious lord.
There is no hurt intended, credit me,
Although a while your freedom be abridg’d.
I know the King: if you would but submit
And write your letters to his Majesty,
Your reconcilement might be easily wrought.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: For what should I submit or ask his mercy?
Had I offended, with all low submission
I’d lay my neck under the blade before him
And willingly endure the stroke of death.
But if not so, why should my fond entreaties
Make my true loyalty appear like treason?
No, no, Lapoole, let guilty men beg pardons;
My mind is clear. And I must tell ye, sir,
Princes have hearts like pointed diamonds
That will in sunder burst afore they bend,
And such lives here, though death King Richard send!
Yet fetch me pen and ink, I’ll write to him,
Not to entreat, but to admonish him
That he forsake his foolish ways in time
And learn to govern like a virtuous prince,
Call home his wise and reverend counselors,
Thrust from his court those cursed flatterers
That hourly works the realm’s confusion.
This counsel if he follow may in time
Pull down those mischiefs that so fast do climb.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Here’s pen and paper, my lord, will’t please ye write?

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Anon I will. Shut to the doors and leave me.
Goodnight, Lapoole, and pardon me, I prithee,
That my sad fear made question of thy faith.
My state is fearful, and my mind was troubled
Even at thy entrance with most fearful visions
Which made my passions more extreme and hasty.
Out of my better judgment I repent it,
And will reward thy love. Once more, good night.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Good rest unto your Grace.
I mean in death.
This dismal night thou breathest thy latest breath.
He sits to write. I’ll call the murderers in,
To steal behind and closely strangle him.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: So help me, heaven, I know not what to write,
What style to use, nor how I should begin.
My method is too plain to greet a king.
I’ll nothing say to excuse or clear myself,
For I have nothing done that needs excuse,
But tell him plain, though here I spend my blood,
I wish his safety and all England’s good.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Creep close to his back, ye rogue, be ready with the towel, when I have knock’d him down, to strangle him.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Do it quickly whilst his back is towards ye, ye damn’d villain; if thou let’st him speak but a word, we shall not kill him.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: I’ll watch him for that. Down on your knees and creep, ye rascal.

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: Have mercy, God! My sight o’ the sudden fails me.
I cannot see my paper,
My trembling fingers will not hold my pen.
A thick congealed mist o’erspreads the chamber.
I’ll rise and view the room.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Not too fast for falling!

speech.speaker: WOOD.
speech.line: What villain hand hath done a deed so bad,
To drench his black soul in a prince’s blood?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Do ye prate, sir? Take that and that! Zounds, put the towel about’s throat and strangle him quickly, ye slave, or by the heart of hell, I’ll fell thee too!

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: ’Tis done, ye damn’d slave. Pull, ye dog, and pull thy soul to hell in doing it, for thou hast kill’d the truest subject that ever breath’d in England.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Pull, rogue, pull! Think of the gold we shall have for doing it, and then let him and thee go to the devil together. Bring in the featherbed and roll him up in that till he be smother’d and stifled, and life and soul press’d out together. Quickly, ye hellhound!

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Here, here, ye cannibal! Zounds, he kicks and sprawls! Lie on’s breast, ye villain!

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Let him sprawl and hang. He’s sure enough for speaking. Pull off the bed now, smooth down his hair and beard. Close his eyes and set his neck right: why, so. All fine and cleanly: who can say that this man was murder’d now?

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: What, is he dead?

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: As a door-nail, my lord. What will ye do with his body?

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Take it up gently, lay him in his bed;
Then shut the door, as if he there had died.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: It cannot be perceived otherwise, my lord. Never was murder done with such rare skill. At our return we shall expect reward, my lord.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: ’Tis ready told. Bear in the body, then return and take it.
Within there, ho!

speech.speaker: 1. TOW. SOLD.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Draw all your weapons, soldiers, guard the room!
There’s two false traitors enter’d the Duke’s chamber,
Plotting to bear him thence, betray the castle,
Deliver up the town and all our lives
To the French forces that are hard at hand
To second their attempts. Therefore stand close
And as they enter seize them presently.
Our will’s your warrant: use no further words
But hew them straight in pieces with your swords.

speech.speaker: 1. TOW. SOLD.
speech.line: I warrant ye, my lord, and their skins were scal’d with brass, we have swords will pierce them. Come, sirs, be ready.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Come, ye miching rascal, the deed’s done and all things perform’d rarely. We’ll take our reward, steal close out o’ the town, buy us fresh geldings, spur, cut and ride till we are past all danger, I warrant thee.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Give their reward there! Quick, I say!

speech.speaker: 2. TOW. SOLD.
speech.line: Down with the traitors! Kill the villains!

speech.speaker: 1. MUR. AND 2. MUR.
speech.line: Hell and the devil! Zounds! Hold, ye rascals!

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Drag hence their bodies, hurl them in the sea:
The black reward of death’s a traitor’s pay.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Tower Soldiers with their bodies.

speech.line: So, this was well perform’d. Now who but we
Can make report of Woodstock’s tragedy?
Only he died a natural death at Calais
So must we give it out, or else King Richard
Through Europe’s kingdoms will be hardly censur’d.
His headstrong uncles, York and Lancaster,
Are up, we hear, in open arms against him;
The gentlemen and commons of the realm,
Missing the good old duke, their plain protector,
Break their allegiance to their sovereign lord
And all revolt upon the barons’ sides;
To help which harm, I’ll o’er to England straight,
And with th’old troops of soldiers ta’en from Calais,
I’ll back King Richard’s power. For should he fail,
And his great uncles get the victory,
His friends are sure to die; but if he win,
They fall and we shall rise, whilst Richard’s king!

stagedir.dir: Drums. March within. Enter Tresilian and Nimble with armor.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: These proclamations we have sent abroad,
Wherein we have accus’d the dukes of treason,
Will daunt their pride and make the people leave them.
I hope no less, at least. Where art thou, Nimble?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: So loaden with armor I cannot stir, my lord.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Whose drums were those that beat even now?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: King Richard’s drums, my lord: the young lords are pressing soldiers.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Oh, and do they take their press with willingness?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: As willing as a punk that’s press’d on a feather-bed they take their pressing apiece with great patience. Marry, the lords no sooner turn their backs but they run away like sheep, sir.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: They shall be hang’d like dogs for’t!
What, dares the slaves refuse their sovereign?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: They say the proclamation’s false, my lord,
And they’ll not fight against the King’s friends.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: So, I fear’d as much. And since ’tis come to this,
I must provide betime and seek for safety,
For now the King and our audacious peers
Are grown to such a height of burning rage
As nothing now can quench their kindled ire
But open trial by the sword and lance;
And then, I fear, King Richard’s part will fail.
Nimble, our soldiers run, thou sayest?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Ay, by my troth, my lord, and I think ’tis our best course to run after them, for if they run now, what will they do when the battle begins? If we tarry here and the King’s uncles catch us, we are sure to be hang’d. My lord, have ye no trick of law to defend us? No demur or writ of error to remove us?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Nimble, we must be wise.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Then let’s not stay to have more wit beaten into our heads; I like not that, my lord.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: I am a man for peace, and not for war.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: And yet they say you have made more wrangling i’ the land than all the wars has done these seven years.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: This battle will revenge their base exclaims.
But hear’st thou, Nimble, I’ll not be there today.
One man amongst so many is no maim,
Therefore I’ll keep aloof till all be done.
If good, I stay; if bad, away I run.
Nimble, it shall be so. I’ll neither fight nor die,
But thus resolv’d, disguise myself and fly.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: ’Tis the wisest course, my lord, and I’ll go put off mine armor that I may run lustily too.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York
John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

stagedir.dir: Enter with drum and colors, York, Lancaster, Arundel and Surrey, with the Duchess of Gloucester weeping, Cheney, and Soldiers.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Go to our tents, dear sister, cease your sorrows.
We will revenge our noble brother’s wrongs,
And force that wanton tyrant to reveal
The death of his dear uncle, harmless Woodstock,
So traitorously betray’d.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Alack, good man,
It was an easy task to work on him,
His plainness was too open to their view.
He fear’d no wrong because his heart was true.
Good sister, cease your weeping, there’s none here
But are as full of woe and touch’d as near.
Conduct and guard her, Cheney, to the tent
Expect to hear severest punishment
