On all their heads that have procur’d his harms,
Struck from the terror of our threatening arms.

speech.speaker: DUCH. GLOS.
speech.line: May all the powers of heaven assist your hands,
And may their sins sit heavy on their souls,
That they in death this day may perish all
That traitorously conspir’d good Woodstock’s fall.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: If he be dead, by good King Edward’s soul,
We’ll call King Richard to a strict account
For that, and for his realm’s misgovernment.

stagedir.dir: Exit the Duchess of Gloucester escorted by Cheney.

speech.line: You peers of England, rais’d in righteous arms
Here to re-edify our country’s ruin,
Join all your hearts and hands never to cease
Till with our swords we work fair England’s peace!

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Most princely Lancaster, our lands and lives
Are to these just proceedings ever vow’d.

speech.speaker: SUR.
speech.line: Those flattering minions that o’erturns the state
This day in death shall meet their endless fate!

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Never such vipers were endur’d so long
To grip and eat the hearts of all the kingdom.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: This day shall here determinate all wrongs.
The meanest man tax’d by their foul oppressions
Shall be permitted freely to accuse,
And right they shall have to regain their own,
Or all shall sink to dark confusion.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: How now, what drums are these?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: To arms, my lords! The minions of the King
Are swiftly marching on to give ye battle!

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: They march to death then, Cheney. Dare the traitors
Presume to brave the field with English princes?

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Where is King Richard? He was resolv’d but lately
To take some hold of strength, and so secure him.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Knowing their states were all so desperate,
It seems they have persuaded otherwise,
For now he comes with full resolve to fight.
Lapoole this morning is arriv’d at court
With the Calais soldiers and some French supplies
To back this now-intended enterprise.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Those new supplies have spurr’d their forward hopes
And thrust their resolutions boldly on
To meet with death and sad destruction.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Their drums are near. Just heaven, direct this deed
And, as our cause deserv’s, our fortunes speed.

stagedir.dir: They march about. Then enter with drum and colors King Richard, Bagot, Bushy, Green, Scroop, Lapoole, and Soldiers. They march about also.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Although we could have easily surpris’d,
Dispers’d and overthrown your rebel troops
That draw your swords against our sacred person,
The highest God’s anointed deputy,
Breaking your holy oaths to heaven and us,
Yet of our mild and princely clemency
We have forborne, that by this parliament
We might be made partaker of the cause
That mov’d ye rise in this rebellious sort.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Hast thou, King Richard, made us infamous
By proclamations false and impudent?
Hast thou condemn’d us in our absence too
As most notorious traitors to the crown?
Betray’d our brother Woodstock’s harmless life,
And sought base means to put us all to death?
And dost thou now plead doltish ignorance
Why we are banded thus in our defense?

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Methinks your treasons to his Majesty,
Raising his subjects ’gainst his royal life,
Should make ye beg for mercy at his feet.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: You have forgotten, uncle Lancaster,
How you in prison murdered cruelly
A friar Carmelite because he was
To bring in evidence against your Grace
Of most ungracious deeds and practices.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: And you, my lord, remember not so well
That by that Carmelite at London once,
When at a supper, you’d have poison’d us.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: For shame, King Richard, leave this company
That like dark clouds obscure the sparkling stars
Of thy great birth and true nobility.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Yield to your uncles! Who but they should have
The guidance of your sacred state and council?

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Yield first your heads, and so he shall be sure
To keep his person and his state secure.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And, by my crown, if still you thus persist,
Your heads and hearts ere long shall answer it.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Not till ye send for more supplies from France,
For England will not yield ye strength to do it.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Thou well may’st doubt their loves, that lost their hearts!
Ungracious prince, cannot thy native country
Find men to back this desperate enterprise?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: His native country? Why, that is France, my lords!
At Bordeaux was he born, which place allures
And ties his deep affections still to France.
Richard is English blood, not English born.
Thy mother travel’d in unhappy hours
When she at Bordeaux left her heavy load.
The soil is fat for wines, not fit for men,
And England now laments that heavy time.
Her royalties are lost, her state made base,
And thou no king but landlord now become
To this great state that terror’d Christendom.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I cannot brook these braves. Let drums sound death,
And strike at once to stop this traitor’s breath!

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Stay, my dear lord; and once more hear me, princes.
The King was minded, ere this brawl began,
To come to terms of composition.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Let him revoke the proclamations,
Clear us of all supposed crimes of treason,
Reveal where our good brother Gloucester keeps,
And grant that these pernicious flatterers
May by the law be tried, to quit themselves
Of all such heinous crimes alleg’d against them,
And we’ll lay down our weapons at thy feet.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Presumptuous traitors!

speech.speaker: KING MEN.
speech.line: Traitors!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Again we double it: rebellious traitors!
Traitors to heaven and us! Draw all your swords
And fling defiance to those traitorous lords!

speech.speaker: KING MEN.
speech.line: Let our drums thunder and begin the fight!

speech.speaker: LORD MEN.
speech.line: Just heaven protect us and defend the right!

scenepersonae.scenepersona: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster
Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Enter Green and Cheney, armed.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Stand, traitor! For thou can’st not ’scape my sword.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: What villain fronts me with the name of traitor?
Was’t thou, false Cheney? Now, by King Richard’s love,
I’ll tilt thy soul out for that base reproach.
I would thy master and the late Protector
With both his treacherous brothers, Gaunt and York,
Were all oppos’d with thee, to try these arms:
I’d seal’t on all your hearts.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: This shall suffice
To free the kingdom from thy villainies!

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Thou hunt’st a noble game, right warlike Cheney:
Cut but this ulcer off, thou heal’st the kingdom.
Yield thee, false traitor, most detested man,
That settest King Richard ’gainst his reverend uncles
To shed the royal bloods and make the realm
Weep for their timeless desolation.
Cast down thy weapons, for by this my sword
We’ll bear thee from this place, alive or dead.

speech.speaker: GREEN.
speech.line: Come both, then! I’ll stand firm and dare your worst!
He that flies from it, be his soul accurs’d!

stagedir.dir: They fight and Green is slain.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: So may the foes of England fall in blood!
Most dissolute traitor! Up with his body, Cheney,
And hale it to the tent of Lancaster.

stagedir.dir: Enter King Richard, Bagot, Bushy, Scroop and soldiers.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Stand firm, my lord, here’s rescue.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Courage, then!
We’ll bear his body hence, in spite of them.

stagedir.dir: They fight. To them enter Lancaster, York, and Surrey, and beats them all away. Manet the King with Green’s corpse.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Oh, princely youth, King Richard’s dearest friend!
What heavy star this day had dominance
To cut off all thy flow’ring youthful hopes?
Prosper, proud rebels, as you dealt by him,
Hard-hearted uncles, unrelenting churls,
That here have murder’d all my earthly joys!
Oh, my dear Green, wert thou alive to see
How I’ll revenge thy timeless tragedy
On all their heads that did but lift a hand
To hurt this body, that I held so dear!
Even by this kiss and by my crown, I swear.

stagedir.dir: Alarum within. Re-enter Bagot, Bushy and Scroop to the King.

speech.speaker: BAG.
speech.line: Away, my lord, stand not to wail his death!
The field is lost; our soldiers shrink and fly:
Lapoole is taken prisoner by the lords.
Hie to the Tower: there is no help in swords.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: Still to continue war were childishness:
Their odds a mountain, ours a molehill is.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Let’s fly to London and make strong the Tower.
Loud proclamations post throughout the camp
With promise of reward to all that take us.
Get safety for our lives, my princely lord,
If here we stay, we shall be all betray’d.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Oh, my dear friends, the fearful wrath of heaven
Sits heavy on our heads for Woodstock’s death.
Blood cries for blood; and that almighty hand
Permits not murder unreveng’d to stand.
Come, come, we yet may hide ourselves from worldly strength,
But heaven will find us out, and strike at length.
Each lend a hand to bear this load of woe
That erst King Richard lov’d and tender’d so.

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Exeunt bearing the body of Green.

scene.scenelocation: A field near the Lords’ camp.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Where art thou, Nimble?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: As light as a feather, my lord. I have put off my shoes that I might run lustily. The battle’s lost and the young lords prisoners. What shall we do, my lord? Yonder’s a stream. We may run along that and ne’er be seen, I warrant.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: I did suspect no less, and so ’tis fall’n:
The day is lost and dash’d are all our hopes.
King Richard’s taken prisoner by the peers.
Oh, that I were upon some steepy rock
Where I might tumble headlong to the sea
Before those cruel lords do seize on me!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Oh, that I were transform’d into a mouse, that I might creep into any hole i’ the house and I car’d not.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Come, Nimble, ’tis no time to use delay.
I’ll keep me in this poor disguise awhile
And so, unknown, prolong my weary life
In hope King Richard shall conclude my peace.
Hark, hark, the trumpets call the soldiers back:
Retreat is sounded! Now the time serves fit
And we may steal from hence. Away, good Nimble!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Nay, stay my lord! ’Slid, and ye go that way, farewell; but an’ you’ll be rul’d by me, I have thought of a trick that ye shall ’scape them all most bravely.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Bethink thyself, good Nimble. Quickly, man!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I’ll meditate, my lord, and then I’m for ye.

Now, Nimble, show thyself a man of valor. Think of thy fortunes: ’tis a hanging matter if thou conceal him. Besides, there’s a thousand marks for him that takes him, with the dukes’ favors, and free pardon. Besides, he’s but a coward, he would ne’er have run from the battle else. Saint Tantony, assist me, I’ll set upon him presently.
My lord, I have thought upon this trick: I must take ye prisoner.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: How, prisoner?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: There’s no way to ’scape else. Then must I carry ye to the King’s uncles, who presently condemns ye for a traitor, sends ye away to hanging, and then ‘God bless my lord Tresilian!’

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Wilt thou betray thy master, villain?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Ay, if my master be a villain. You think ’tis nothing for a man to be hang’d for his master? You heard not the proclamation?

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: What proclamation?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Oh, sir, all the country’s full of them that whosoever sees you and does not presently take ye and bring ye to the Lords shall be hang’d for his labor. Therefore, no more words, lest I raise the whole camp upon ye. Ye see one of your own swords of justice drawn over ye, therefore go quietly lest I cut your head off and save the hangman a labor.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Oh, villain!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: No more words. Away, sir!

scenepersonae.scenepersona: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster
Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

stagedir.dir: Sound a retreat, then a flourish, and enter victoriously with drums and colors Lancaster, Arundel, Surrey, Cheney and Soldiers with Lapoole, Bushy and Scroop as prisoners.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Thus princely Edward’s sons, in tender care
Of wanton Richard and their father’s realm,
Have toil’d to purge fair England’s pleasant field
Of all those rancorous weeds that chok’d the grounds
And left her pleasant meads like barren hills.
Who is’t can tell us which way Bagot fled?

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Some say to Bristowe, to make strong the castle.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: See that the port’s belay’d. He’ll fly the land,
For England hath no hold can keep him from us.
Had we Tresilian hang’d, then all were sure.
Where slept our scouts, that he escap’d the field?

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: He fled, they say, before the fight began.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Our proclamations soon shall find him forth,
The root and ground of all these vile abuses.

stagedir.dir: Enter Nimble with Tresilian bound and guarded.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: How now, what guard is that? What traitor’s there?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: The traitor now is ta’en.
I here present the villain,
And if ye needs will know his name,
God bless my lord Tresilian.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: Tresilian, my lord, attach’d and apprehended by his man!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Yes, and it please ye, my lord, ’twas I that took him. I was once a trampler in the law after him, and I thank him he taught me this trick, to save myself from hanging.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Thou’rt a good lawyer, and hast remov’d the cause from thyself fairly.

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: I have remov’d it with a Habeas Corpus, and then I took him with a Surssararis, and bound him in this bond to answer it. Nay, I have studied for my learning, I can tell ye, my lord. There was not a stone between Westminster Hall and Temple Bar but I have told them every morning.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: What moved thee, being his man, to apprehend him?

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Partly for these causes: first, the fear of the proclamation, for I have plodded in Plowden and can find no law that doth protect this traitor from your Graces’ justice. And second, for the money promis’d, and third, because he did most treacherously command the murder of the Duke of Gloucester, Thomas of Woodstock.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Oh, ’tis a warrant for my brother’s death!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: Aye, writ of my Lord Chief Injustice here.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: ‘See thou no marks nor violence show upon him, that we may say he naturally died.’
Oh, scoundrel, for this shalt thou most violent and unnaturally die!

stagedir.dir: Shows parchment to Surrey and Arundel.

speech.speaker: SUR.
speech.line: Oh, monstrous!

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Thou false traitor and injurious villain,
To hell’s eternal torments art thou damn’d.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Great lords, I plead the ancient privilege of law
To put in bail and appeal the charge.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: By Heav’n, we’ll hear no more, the proof’s too plain.
Away with him to Radcot Castle and death’s pain.

speech.speaker: TRES.
speech.line: Mercy, great Lancaster! Oh, help me, Nimble!

speech.speaker: NIM.
speech.line: God bless my lord Tresilian.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Now, Bushy, freely speak thy mind.
What dost thou know of noble Gloucester’s death?

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: I ever honor’d and rever’d the worthy Duke.
’Twas Bagot, Scroop, Tresilian and the rest
Contriv’d against my Lord Protector’s life.

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: Nay, by Lapoole was he most cruelly kill’d.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: Not so, my lords, at Callice was our watch
Deceiv’d by murd’rers that his Majesty did send,
Who chok’d the goodly kind old man. Yet still
I do repent that in my rage I slew
The villains both and cast their bloody limbs
From off the battlements into the sea.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: So art thou doubly damn’d, Lapoole,
For Woodstock’s bloody death and theirs.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: But yet have mercy lords, it was the King
Commanded us. It is the King who is to blame.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: King Richard did decree it, sayest thou?
We’ll fetch him in.

speech.speaker: CHEN.
speech.line: The Duke of York attends him. I’ll be their conduct.

speech.speaker: LAP.
speech.line: His Majesty did order Woodstock’s death.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: Aye, ’twas the King. ‘Beware, plain Thomas,’
Thus said he, ‘for Richard comes
To wash away with blood all former wrongs!’

speech.speaker: SCR.
speech.line: ’Tis true, my lords, King Richard did require it.

stagedir.dir: Re-enter Cheney with King Richard, York, and Officers bearing crown and scepter. Scroop and Bushy kneel.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I pray you, mock me not. You see I am a king in chains.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: King Richard, though our prisoner, art thou still
The first of princely Edward’s royal blood,
And we your faithful subjects, staunch and true.
Nay, coz, turn not thy kingly face away,
We yet do bear the sad and heavy death
Of Thomas Woodstock, thy kind uncle and our kin.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I am so weary, sirs.
I mourn him also, uncle, God rest good
Gloucester’s soul.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Stand up, Richard. These traitors here maintain
That you decreed thy father’s brother’s death.
Here is thy warrant with Tresilian’s seal.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why then they lie, ’twas done without my wish,
For Gloucester’s grievous death I urg’d it not.
Bushy, thou know’st I did command no gall
To our belov’d Protector should befall.

speech.speaker: BUSH.
speech.line: He did, my lords, and we endeavored so.

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Yet is he dead.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Good uncles, I acknowledge my disgrace,
I did neglect my duty in that case.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Your duty, nephew, aye, and what of ours,
Whose honor and allegiance thus are torn
Betwixt our murder’d kinsman and our king?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I am thy kinsman, uncle, and your king,
And with thee grieve most sore for Woodstock’s death.
But, uncle York, and you most noble peers,
Anointed am I still with holy oil,
Thy coronation oaths, my crown, and scepter royal.
Nor tears, nor blood nor waters in the sea
Can off my kingly brow take that from me.

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: He is our king, whom we may not depose,
Lest harshly plucking we destroy fair England’s rose.

speaker.long: Edmund of Langley, Duke of York

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: What says our brother Lancaster?

speaker.long: John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Edmund, I do believe he wish’d no harm,
We’ll pardon him as God shall pardon us
That righteously have sought to cleanse this land.
Besides, Tresilian and Lapoole hath both confess’d;
To end the matter here methinks ’tis best.
See execution’s done, take him away.
The sable night of death shall close his day.
Although of Woodstock’s murder you’re acquit,
Thy kingdom, Richard, must be set aright,
For all the Commons and assembl’d peers
In univocal clamor do require it. Take off his chains.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thank you, sir. What must I do, my lords?

speech.speaker: ARUN.
speech.line: Dismiss these baneful flatterers your court,
Cancel the proclamations of our treachery,
Receive us back into your Council’s heart.
Then all shall be as it first was before,
And thy bright crown and kingdom we’ll restore.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Hear all, we do revoke our royal word,
Vacate the proclamations and abjure the charge,
Recall our uncles Lancaster and York,
And to our Council re-admit these earls.
With Bagot art thou now dismiss’d the court,
Remov’d from office and thy powers revok’d.
Come not again near to us by ten mile.

speech.speaker: SUR.
speech.line: The Commons beg revocation of the Charters, sir.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We do repent us now of those Blank Charters,
Repeal the law, and further here proclaim
We grieve most sore the death of our Protector,
Good, plain and loving Thomas, villainously slain.
Lancaster hands him the crown
Redeem’d, restored and renew’d, we vow
In fresh humility our realm to crown
With justice, truth and amity of God.
No more a pelting farm, yet once again
An England that’s a royal seat of kings.
God save the soul of Thomas Woodstock!

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: God save the soul of Thomas Woodstock!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And now, my lords, to Windsor, if you will,
For there awaits, we hear, the Commons and the peers
With whom we would be sweetly reconcil’d,
That peace may claim new fruits and harvests mild.
Away, let neither king nor kingdom stand!
Forever now a joyous, happier land.
